questions.text: A 65-year-old woman began experiencing visuospatial impairment. It progressed from forgetting trivial things and led to her present condition. She was diagnosed with Alzheimer's disease; wherein neurotoxic substances cross the blood-brain barrier and contribute to dementia. Which of the following cells might be malfunctioning which can lead to a disruption of the blood-brain barrier?
questions.solution:
Astrocytes are neuroectodermal derivatives responsible for maintaining the blood-brain barrier.

Oligodendrocytes are glial cells responsible for myelin sheath formation in the CNS. They are neuroectodermal in origin. They are also implicated in the pathogenesis of Alzheimer's disease but they do not contribute to the blood-brain barrier.

In the peripheral nervous system, Schwann cells are responsible for myelination. They are neural crest cell derivatives. They are affected in Multiple sclerosis, which is an autoimmune disorder.

Ependymal cells are found in the lining of ventricles.


Reference: BD Chaurasia's Human Anatomy, regional and applied, 8th edition, page no 3.

questions.text: Suxamethonium may cause
questions.solution:
Suxamethonium is a depolarizing neuromuscular blocker.

Side effects include -

  • Single or repeated doses of suxamethonium can cause bradycardia.
  • Histamine release is not uncommon.
  • Both salivation and gastric secretions are increased.
  • Intracranial and intraocular pressures are increased.
  • Muscle pains are particularly common in young, muscular patients.
  • Increased susceptibility to malignant hyperthermia.

Reference: Pinnock CA, Lin ES, Smith T. Fundamentals of Anaesthesia, 2nd Edn. Greenwich Medical Media Ltd, 2003, Section 3: Chapter 8.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman has a cord-like rash on her left calf that is red and painful to touch. She has had 3 past spontaneous abortions at < 10 weeks of gestational age. In addition, she has a lacy mottled violaceous rash on multiple extremities. Which of the following antibodies would most likely be found in this patient's blood?
questions.solution:
This patient with thrombophlebitis, recurrent fetal loss, and a livido reticularis rash on her extremities most likely have antiphospholipid syndrome, which is associated with the anti-cardiolipin antibody.

  • Antiphospholipid syndrome is an autoimmune disorder that is often associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), characterized by thromboses and recurrent spontaneous abortions.
  • Its pathogenesis involves autoantibodies such as lupus anticoagulant, anti-cardiolipin, and anti-β2 glycoprotein that react against platelet membranes or the prothrombin-platelet membrane complex.
  • This autoimmune reaction subsequently activates endothelial cells and platelets leading to the coagulopathic effects that are seen in this disorder.

Other Options:

Option B: Anti-centromere antibodies would be associated with limited scleroderma (CREST syndrome); however, this disorder would not present with recurrent fetal loss and thrombosis.

Option C: Anti-helicase antibodies would be associated with dermatomyositis and polymyositis; however, this disorder would not present with recurrent fetal loss and thrombosis.

Option D: Anti-histone antibodies would be associated with drug-induced lupus; however, there is no indication that this patient has taken any drugs that would lead to lupus such as procainamide.

Reference: Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas, and Aster, 10th Edition, Page Number 441.

questions.text: A 53-year-old hypertensive man suffered from a hypertensive bleed in the CNS, and his brain imaging implicated bleed from the Posterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery. Apart from other localizing features, which of the following symptom would differentiate lateral medullary syndrome from lateral pontine syndrome?
questions.solution:
Both lateral pontine and medullary syndromes have similar features, namely-

  • Vestibular involvement- Nystagmus, vertigo
  • Spinothalamic tract- Contralateral loss of pain and temperature
  • Sympathetic tract- Horner's syndrome
  • Spinal nucleus of trigeminal- Ipsilateral facial numbness

However, in addition to these, the lateral medullary syndrome also involves nucleus ambiguous, thus, hoarseness of voice and dysphagia is seen.


Features of Lateral pontine syndrome aka Marie Foix disease can be remembered as - ASH

  • Ataxia
  • Spinothalamic involvement
  • Hemiplegia

Reference: BD Chaurasia's Human Anatomy, regional and applied, 8th edition, page 100

choices.text: Confirmatory findings of acute pancreatitis on cross-sectional abdominal imaging
Threefold or greater elevation in serum lipase and/or amylase
Typical abdominal pain in the epigastrium that may radiate to the back

questions.text: A 42-year-old male is admitted with severe epigastric pain radiating to the back. You suspect acute pancreatitis. All of the following are accepted diagnostic criteria for acute pancreatitis except
questions.solution:
Any severe acute pain in the abdomen or back should suggest the possibility of acute pancreatitis. The diagnosis is established by two of the following three criteria:

  • Typical abdominal pain in the epigastrium that may radiate to the back
  • Threefold or greater elevation in serum lipase and/or amylase
  • Confirmatory findings of acute pancreatitis on cross-sectional abdominal imaging.

Many patients with acute pancreatitis have concomitant hypoxemia and may even develop acute respiratory distress syndrome, but hypoxemia is not a diagnostic criterion for acute pancreatitis.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 21st edition, page no 2660.

questions.text: Mrs. Santosh is a 50-year-old woman suffering from Graves disease, for which she is taking carbimazole. She recently forgot to take her medication for 2 days, following which she developed tachycardia, restlessness, and hyperthermia. She was admitted for a thyroid storm and was managed appropriately. However, on admission day 2, she developed chest pain, tachycardia, and pedal edema of pitting type. Her ECG showed sinus tachycardia and her ECHO suggested CHF. The physician suspected CHF due to thyrotoxicosis. Which of the following cannot be administered in this scenario for managing CHF?
questions.solution:
Thyrotoxicosis is a known cause of precipitating CHF due to the high cardiac output state being created. In such cases, digoxin is contraindicated because thyrotoxicosis predisposes one to digoxin-induced arrhythmias.

Similarly, hypothyroidism decreases the clearance of digoxin and thus precipitates toxicity.

Contraindications of digoxin include-

  • Hypokalemia - causes toxicity
  • Myocardial infarction
  • WPW syndrome - ventricular fibrillation may occur due to reduced ERP of bypass
  • Elderly, renal, or severe hepatic disease - more sensitive to digitalis
  • Ventricular tachyarrhythmias
  • Thyrotoxicosis

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 560.

choices.text: A computed tomography (CT) scan in both coronal and axial planes
A microbiology swab is taken from the middle meatus
Surgical correction of the deviated nasal septum and reduction of the inferior turbinate

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl complains of unilateral nasal obstruction that has been long-standing. This is associated with unilateral discharge that can be discolored. On examination, the left side of the nose is narrowed, and although the middle meatus looks normal, a clear view of the entire nasal cavity cannot be obtained with either rigid or flexible endoscopy. The next most useful investigation would be
questions.solution:
The differential diagnosis would include chronic rhinosinusitis, unilateral choanal atresia, the presence of a foreign body, and any other pathology in the postnasal space.

A CT scan performed in both the coronal and axial planes would enable these conditions to be distinguished and appropriate treatment is undertaken.

Microbiology, although it may demonstrate the presence of infection, particularly anaerobes in association with a foreign body, will not help definitively to distinguish these conditions.

An examination under anesthesia may be ultimately required; it should not be undertaken without appropriate imaging.

A considerable amount of septal and turbinate surgery is undertaken inappropriately without the elimination of other contributory or underlying pathology.

Although acoustic rhinometry can help to quantify the topography of the nose, it becomes increasingly less accurate in the posterior part of the nasal cavity and postnasal space and may be distorted by the presence of secretions.

Reference: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition, chapter no 33, Acute and Chronic Nasal Disorders, page no 750.

questions.text: A 16-year-old male patient came to OPD with a chief complaint of diminution of vision in both eyes for 2 years with frequent changes of glasses. On slit lamp examination ectatic corneal protrusion was seen. Which sign is not seen in the condition described above?
questions.solution:
The condition described here is keratoconus. Stocker's line is not seen in keratoconus.


Stocker's line is an iron deposition line in the corneal epithelium, seen at the corneal leading edge of a pterygium.

Signs of keratoconus-

  1. External signs:
    • Munson's sign - Bulging of the lower lid when a patient looks downwards.
    • Rizzuti phenomenon - A sharply focused conical beam of light near the nasal limbus, produced by lateral illumination of the cornea from the temporal side.
  2. Slit lamp findings
    • Stromal thinning
    • Posterior stress lines (Vogt's striae)
    • Iron ring (Fleischer's ring) - at the base of the conical protrusion
    • Scarring-epithelial or subepithelial
  3. Retroillumination signs
    • Scissoring on retinoscopy
    • Oil droplet sign ('Charleaux')
  4. Photokeratoscopy signs
    • Compression of mires inferotemporally ('egg-shaped' mires)
    • Compression of mires inferiorly or centrally

Reference: Parson 22/e, Pg 67

choices.text: Bound medially by Abductor pollicis longus
Bound laterally by Extensor polices brevis
Floor is formed by base of 1st metacarpal bone

questions.text: A 34-year-old alcoholic fell on his outstretched hand and later presented with pain in the anatomical snuff box. Which of the following is incorrect with respect to this structure?
questions.solution:
Boundaries of Anatomical Snuff box-

Medially- Extensor policis longus

Laterally- Abductor policis longus and extensor policis brevis

Roof- Skin, superficial fascia, deep fascia, cephalic vein, superficial branch of radial nerve

Floor- Lower end of radius, scaphoid, trapezium, base of 1st metacarpal

Content - Radial artery


Reference: BD Chaurasia's human anatomy, regional and applied, 8th edition, volume-1, page no 144.

questions.text:
A 12-year-old boy returned from a party and began vomiting 4-5 hours later, followed by a few episodes of loose stools but had no fever. 0ther children who had attended the party reported a similar illness. Food samples were collected and sent for toxin detection by a test based on the following principle.

This test is known as
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of food Poisoning caused by Staphylococcus aureus.

  • The symptoms of food poisoning caused by S aureus appear within 1-8 hours.
  • Multiple people are exposed to the pathogen from a common source and present with vomiting and loose stools but no fever.
  • Foods from outbreaks of food poisoning are examined for the presence of Staphylococcal enterotoxin A (SEA) by a sandwich ELISA.

Sandwich ELISA (shown in the image) is used for antigen detection in the patient samples. The antigen is sandwiched between two layers of antibodies capture and detection antibodies.

Other options:

Cassette ELISA: Here, each specimen is tested in a separate disposable cassette and gives rapid results (10-75 minutes). There is no need for microplate washers or readers.

Competitive ELISA: Both the unknown antigen (sample) and the known antigen (standard) compete with each other for a fixed amount of antibody.

Indirect ELISA: Antibody in the sample can be detected or quantitatively measured using this method. Serum or some other sample containing primary antibody (Ab)) is added to an antigen.


Reference: Ananthanarayan and Panikers Textbook of Microbiology Tenth edition, pg no 116.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male have come with a complaint of left groin swelling to your OPD. After clinical examination, it was found that the patient has recurrent left inguinal hernia with a defect size of approximately 3 cm. Classify this hernia as per the EHS classification.
questions.solution:
The European Hernia Society has recently suggested a simplified system of classification of hernias.

  • Primary or Recurrent (P or R)
  • Lateral, Medial, or Femoral (L, M, or F)
  • Defect size in fingerbreadths assumed to be 1.5 cm.

A recurrent, direct, inguinal hernia with a 3-cm defect size would be RM2.

Reference: Bailey and Love 27th edition, Pg No 1031.

questions.text: Which of the following is correctly matched with respect to abduction at the shoulder joint?
questions.solution:
Shoulder joint abduction requires glenohumeral elevation and scapular rotation in a 2:1 ration.

  • 0-150- Supraspinatus
  • 15-900- Deltoid
  • 90-1800- Trapezius and Serratus Anterior

Reference: BD Chaurasia's human anatomy, regional and applied, 8th edition, volume-1 page 73.

questions.text: The epithelium shown in the image is not seen in the lining of which of the following organs?
questions.solution:
The epithelium shown in the image is urothelium or transitional epithelium with apical umbrella-like cells flattening into simple squamous cells as we go towards the base.

The transitional epithelium is mainly seen in the lining of the urinary system, from the tip of the collecting duct to the prostatic urethra (minor and major calyces, renal pelvis, ureter, urinary bladder, and prostatic urethra).


Simple cuboidal epithelium is seen in renal tubules.


Reference: Inderbir Singh's textbook of human histology, 8th edition, page 25

questions.text: The patient seen in the image below is likely to develop which of the following ocular complication?
questions.solution:
The image shows a unilateral, painful, vesicular rash suggestive of herpes zoster opthalmicus (HZO). It is caused by the reactivation of varicella-zoster virus within the branches of the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve.

Features of herpes-zoster ophthalmicus (HZO) -

Corneal lesion:

  • Nummular keratitis
  • Pseudo-dendritic ulcer (terminal knobs absent)

Other ocular lesions that can be seen include -

  • Uveitis
  • Episcleritis and scleritis
  • Conjunctivitis
  • Acute retinal necrosis
  • Secondary glaucoma

Treatment for HZO:

Oral acyclovir 800 mg 5 times daily for 10-14 days.

  • There is no use for topical antivirals.
  • Lubricants
  • Tarsorrhaphy in severe cases of neurotrophic keratitis.

Treatment of postherpetic neuralgia:

  • Capsaicin cream applied to the skin
  • Low doses of amitriptyline or carbamazepine
  • Oral gabapentin

Dendritic ulcers are seen in HSV keratitis.

Reference: Parson 22/e, Pg. 57.

questions.text: A 64-year-old woman presented with hyponatremia. On further workup, it was found that she has SIADH. What is the embryological origin of the organ that stores this hormone?
questions.solution:
ADH is secreted from the hypothalamus and via the hypothalamic-pituitary stalk. It is stored in the posterior pituitary gland.

The posterior pituitary or pars nervosa develops from Neuroectoderm.


Reference: textbook of clinical embryology, Vishram Singh, 12 edition, page 275

questions.text: A 2-day-old neonate was brought with non-bilious projectile vomiting. The pediatrician suggests that it could be due to the failure of fusion of the ventral pancreatic bud with the dorsal. Which of the following signs will be seen on X-ray?
questions.solution:
• Annular pancreas (AP) is a rare congenital anomaly characterized by encasement of the duodenum by a band of pancreatic tissue.
  • Symptoms from the annular pancreas are nausea, vomiting, a feeling of fullness after eating, and feeding problems in newborns.
  • Surgical bypass of the obstructing segment of the duodenum is the usual treatment for this disorder.

  • On x-ray, it shows a double bubble sign, due to loss of continuity of duodenum.

Single bubble is seen in congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis.

Triple bubble is seen in jejunal atresia.

Double bleb sign is seen in the second week of conception as the yolk sac and amniotic cavity are visualized on ultrasound.

Reference: textbook of clinical embryology, Vishram Singh, 12 edition, page 140.

choices.text: In the Shouldice method, double breasting of fascia transversalis and of external oblique aponeurosis is done
Maloney procedure is intermittent, non-absorbable nylon or polypropylene suture which is darned between the conjoint tendon and inguinal ligament
Desarda has described an operation where a 1- to 2-cm strip of external oblique aponeurosis is sutured to the conjoint tendon and inguinal ligament
Hernia system is the method in which inner layer of mesh is lying deep to the fascia transversalis and outer layer superficial to it

questions.text: All of the following is true regarding hernia repair except?
questions.solution:
In Maloney procedure, continuous, non-absorbable nylon or polypropylene suture is darned between the conjoint tendon and inguinal ligament.

In Shouldice modification, the transversalis fascia is opened by a central incision from the deep inguinal ring to the pubic tubercle and then closed to create a double-thick, two-layered posterior wall (double breasting). The external oblique is closed in a similar fashion.

Desarda has described an operation where a 1- to 2-cm strip of external oblique aponeurosis lying over the inguinal canal is isolated from the main muscle but left attached both medially and laterally. It is then sutured to the conjoint tendon and inguinal ligament, reinforcing the posterior wall of the inguinal canal.

A two-layered mesh (hernia system), in which the inner layer is placed deep to transversalis fascia and the outer layer superficial to it, is also gaining popularity.

Reference: Bailey and Love 27th edition, Pg No 1033.

choices.text: Bound anteriorly by the right free margin of lesser omentum
Bound anteriorly by right free margin of greater omentum
Bound superiorly by the first part of duodenum

questions.text: A 33-year-old presented with trauma to the right hypochondrium and bruising at right-sided 9, 10, and 11 ribs after an RTA. His vitals were - Temperature- 98.9F, pulse- 120bpm, RR- 14 per min, and BP-98/62 mmHg. eFAST revealed collection in the hepatorenal pouch of Morrison. Suspecting liver trauma, resuscitative measures were carried out. The pringle maneuver was performed to check bleeding. Which of the following is true regarding the boundaries of the site where this maneuver is performed?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette along with eFAST suggest liver trauma. Pringle's maneuver is done in this case to

  • Immediately stop further blood loss
  • Determine the origin of hemorrhage
  • Control the hemorrhage
  • Repair injured blood vessels

It is also performed in other liver surgeries.

A clamp is applied at the hepatoduodenal ligament at the epiploic foramen. If the bleeding stops, it is due to the portal vein, if not, hepatic vein is implicated, since it is not part of the portal triad of portal vein, bile duct, and hepatic artery and is hence not clamped in this maneuver.


The epiploic foramen is the connection between lesser sac and greater sac.

It is bound -

  • Anteriorly by a right free margin of lesser omentum
  • Posteriorly by IVC
  • Superiorly by a caudate lobe of liver
  • Inferiorly by the first part of duodenum


Reference: BD Chaurasia's Human Anatomy, regional and applied, 8th edition, volume 2, page 270.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old man was admitted to the ward with complaints of high-grade fever, and cough with expectoration for 15 days. He was later diagnosed with pleural effusion due to pneumonia, for which pleural tapping had to be done. Arrange the following muscles in the order in which they are pierced.
1. External intercostal muscle
2. Internal intercostal muscle
3. Serratus anterior
4. Innermost intercostal muscle
questions.solution:
Pleural tapping is done at the upper border of the lower rib to prevent damage to neurovascular structures present on the lower border.

It is done in the mid-axillary line at 7,8,9 intercostal spaces.

The structures pierced are-

  1. Skin
  2. Superficial fascia
  3. Deep fascia
  4. Serratus anterior
  5. External intercostal muscle
  6. Internal intercostal muscle
  7. Innermost intercostal muscle- gives giving away feeling
  8. Endothoracic fascia
  9. Parietal pleura

Reference: BD Chaurasia's human anatomy, regional and applied, 8th edition, volume-1 page 240.

choices.text: Study A, because it has a superior surgeon
Study A, because it is a multi-center trial
Study B, because it has a larger sample size
Study B, because it is double-blinded

questions.text: A grant reviewer at the Indian Council of Medical Research is determining which of the two studies investigating the effects of gastric bypass surgery on fasting blood sugar to fund. Study A is spearheaded by a world-renowned surgeon, is a multi-center study planning to enroll 50 patients at each of 5 different sites, and is single-blinded. Study B plans to enroll 300 patients from a single site and will be double-blinded by virtue of a sham surgery for the control group. The studies both plan to use a t-test, and they both report identical expected treatment effect sizes and variance. If the reviewer were interested only in which trial has the higher power, which proposal should he fund?
questions.solution:
The power of a study is proportional to the sample size. As such, all else being equal, the larger a study the greater the power.

The power of a study is its ability to detect an association when one truly exists.

In the proposed pair of studies, the investigators hope to avoid both Type I errors/alpha (claiming an association when one doesn't exist) and Type II errors/beta (failing to detect a true association).

Power is the probability of not making a Type II error. Historically, the most commonly used values for alpha and beta are 0.05 and 0.20, respectively. The power of a study is usually calculated before the actual study is performed, either to determine the number of patients needed to be enrolled to achieve a certain power or if the sample size is predetermined, what the power is expected to be.

Reference: Textbook of Preventive & Social Medicine, by K. Park, 26th Edition, Page Number 60.

questions.text: 60-year-old female patient complaints of pain in her knee bilaterally, the pain increases while going up and down the stairs. The x-ray shows bilateral reduced joint space, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Osteoarthritis is the most common form of arthritis, affecting millions of people worldwide. It occurs when the protective cartilage that cushions the ends of the bones wears down over time. Although osteoarthritis can damage any joint, the disorder most commonly affects joints in your

knees, hands, hips, and spine.

Radiological features of osteoarthritis

  • Joint space reduction (due to loss of cartilage)
  • Osteophytes formation
  • Subchondral sclerosis (due to condensation of trabeculae)
  • Subchondral cyst formation (due to sipping on of synovial fluid into cracks)


Reference: Maheshwari ortho 5th edition, page no 295.

choices.text: The K-ras oncogene is currently thought to be the most commonly mutated gene in pancreatic cancer, with approximately 90% of tumors having a mutation
About two-thirds of pancreatic adenocarcinomas arise in the body region of the pancreas
Exome capture technology combined with SOLiD are used to investigate the genetic landscape of pancreatic adenocarcinoma
Acinar cell carcinoma has a better prognosis than ductal carcinoma

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding pancreatic cancers except?
questions.solution:
About two-thirds of pancreatic adenocarcinomas arise within the head or uncinate process of the pancreas; 15% are in the body, and 10% are in the tail, with the remaining tumors demonstrating diffuse involvement of the gland.

Option a) The K-ras oncogene is currently thought to be the most commonly mutated gene in pancreatic cancer, with approximately 90% of tumors having a mutation.

Option c ) The genetic landscape of pancreatic adenocarcinoma has recently been investigated using exome capture technology combined with the SOLiD or Illumina next-generation sequencing platforms and copy number analysis

Option d) Acinar cell carcinoma is an uncommon type of pancreatic cancer that usually presents as a large tumor, often 10 cm in diameter or more, but the prognosis of patients with these tumors may be better than with ductal cancer.

Reference: Schwartz 11e, Pg No 1485.

choices.text: Lies between the spinal dura mater and the arachnoid mater
The epidural anesthetic of choice given for labour is lignocaine

questions.text: Regarding the epidural space of the spine, the wrong statement is
questions.solution:
• The epidural space is open laterally to the intervertebral foramina.
  • It lies outside of the dura mater, between the dura and ligamentum flavum.
  • Bupivacaine is the anesthetic of choice in epidural anesthesia for labour.

Reference: Pinnock CA, Lin ES, Smith T. Fundamentals of Anaesthesia, 2nd Edn. Greenwich Medical Media Ltd, 2003, Section 1: Chapter 5, Section 2: Chapter 9.

questions.text: Which of the following is best described by the image shown below?
questions.solution:
The image depicts smothering. It refers to the blockage of the external air passages, usually by a hand or soft fabric.

Mechanical asphyxia can be classified depending on the respiratory block:

  • Compression/constriction of the neck - Hanging, strangulation, throttling
  • Blocking external orifices of respiration, i.e. mouth and/or nostrils - Smothering, overlying, suffocation, gagging
  • Impaction of foreign bodies in the respiratory tract - Choking
  • Compression and mechanical fixation of the chest and abdomen preventing the respiratory movements - Traumatic asphyxia/crush asphyxia
  • Inhalation of fluid into the respiratory tract - Drowning

Reference: Essentials of Autopsy Practice: Advances, Updates, and Emerging Technologies Page no 23.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents with deterioration of vision 3 weeks after cataract extraction and IOL implantation. Slit lamp examination shows honeycomb maculopathy and Fluorescein (FA) shows 'flower petal' hyperfluorescence. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is cystoid macular edema (CME).

CME results from the accumulation of fluid in the outer plexiform and inner nuclear layers of the retina with the formation of tiny cyst-like cavities. Fluid may initially accumulate intracellularly in Muller cells, with subsequent rupture.

Causes of CME include

  • Ocular surgery and laser. Ex: phacoemulsification, pan-retinal photocoagulation, and miscellaneous other procedures.
  • Retinal vascular disease. Ex: Diabetic retinopathy
  • Inflammation. Ex: intermediate uveitis, severe or chronic uveitis of any kind.
  • Drug-induced. Ex. topical prostaglandin derivatives.
  • Retinal dystrophies. Ex: retinitis pigmentosa.
  • Conditions involving vitreomacular traction.
  • Fundus Ex: retinal capillary haemangioma.
  • Systemic disease, e.g. chronic renal failure.

The symptoms of CME include blurring, distortion of vision, and micropsia.

The signs seen in CME include -

  • Loss of the foveal depression.
  • Thickening of the retina and multiple cystoid areas in the sensory retina.
  • Slit lamp examination - Honeycomb pattern of macula
  • Fluorescein angiography (FA) - A petaloid pattern is seen due to dye accumulation in microcystic spaces in the outer plexiform layer.

Reference: Kanski 7/e, pg. 630.

choices.text: It is part of the hypopharynx
Sensory supply is by recurrent laryngeal nerve
It is bound medially by an aryepiglottic fold

questions.text: A 7-year-old child had choked on a fish bone, which was seen in the space shown below. Which of the following is incorrect about this space?
questions.solution:
The space highlighted in the image and the history of choking on a fish bone by a child suggests that this space is the pyriform fossa.

The pyriform sinus (piriform sinus/pyriform recess/ pyriform fossa/smuggler's fossa) is the pear-shaped subsite of the hypopharynx (laryngopharynx) located posterolaterally to either side of the laryngeal opening.

Relations and/or boundaries-

  • Medially by the aryepiglottic fold and arytenoid and cricoid cartilages
  • Laterally by the thyroid cartilage and thyrohyoid membrane
  • Superiorly by the level of the hyoid bone
  • Inferiorly by the level of the inferior border of the cricoid cartilage

Beneath the mucous membrane of the anterior wall runs the internal laryngeal nerve, a branch of the superior laryngeal nerve.


Reference: BD Chaurasia's human anatomy, regional and applied, 8th edition, volume-3 page 286.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man presented to ER with symmetrical polyarthritis, left upper arm joint deformity, and low back pain. X-ray imaging of the hands demonstrated bilateral erosions and deformities of the carpal bones, and the left arm showed mixed lytic and sclerotic bone lesions. Laboratory tests showed high levels of rheumatoid factor. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points towards Rheumatoid arthritis with deformity.

Methotrexate with anti-TNF is superior to any other treatment in limiting joint destruction and disability.

Following combinations can be used in the above scenario:

  • Methotrexate, sulfasalazine, and hydroxychloroquine (Oral triple therapy).
  • Methotrexate and leflunomide.
  • Methotrexate and a biological such as anti-TNF.

Reference: Harrisons principle of internal medicine 20th ed pg no:2539.

questions.text: The incidence of hepatitis A infection was found to be 25%, and the total number of deaths recorded among the incident cases was 5 individuals of 500 total population. What was the case-fatality rate for the hepatitis A outbreak?
questions.solution:
The incidence of hepatitis A infection was 25% among the total number of individuals who dined at the restaurant during the week of study. Thus, the number of new cases of hepatitis A infection was (0.25) * 500 = 125 individuals. There were 5 total deaths from hepatitis A infection among the incident cases.

The case-fatality rate is thus equal to (5/125) * 100% = 4%.

Reference: Textbook of Preventive & Social Medicine, by K. Park, 26th Edition, Page Number 6.

questions.text: Narendra was posted for parotidectomy for cancerous growth. Upon post-operative follow-up, he complained of sweating on the face everytime he chewed his meals. This anomaly occurs due to aberrant regeneration of which of the following cranial nerve branch?
questions.solution:
Frey syndrome is a rare disorder that most often occurs as a result of surgery in the area near the parotid glands.

  • The characteristic symptom of Frey syndrome is gustatory sweating, which is excessive sweating on the cheek, forehead, and around the ears shortly after eating certain foods, specifically foods that produce a strong salivary response such as sour, spicy, or salty foods.
  • Additional symptoms include flushing and warmth in the affected areas.

In Frey syndrome, it is believed that damaged AURICULOTEMPORAL nerve fibers (branch of the posterior division of mandibular nerve) regenerate abnormally by growing along the sympathetic fiber pathways, ultimately connecting to the miniscule sweat glands found along the skin.

Therefore, the parasympathetic nerves that normally tell the parotid glands to produce saliva in response to tasting food now respond by instructing the sweat glands to produce sweat and the blood vessels to widen (dilate). The cumulative result is excessive sweating and flushing when eating certain foods.


Reference: BD Chaurasia's human anatomy, regional and applied, 8th edition, volume-3 page 114.

choices.text: A thickened peripheral nerve with weakness of muscles supplied by them
The presence of acid-fast bacilli in nerve biopsy
Definite loss of sensation in hypopigmented patch

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the cardinal features of leprosy?
questions.solution:
The WHO expert committee on leprosy has defined a case of leprosy as an individual who has one of the following cardinal signs of leprosy but who has not received a full course of multi-drug therapy (MDT) for the type of leprosy identified:

  • A definite loss of sensation in a pale (hypopigmented) or reddish skin patch
  • A thickened or enlarged peripheral nerve with a loss of sensation and/or weakness in the muscles supplied by the nerve
  • The presence of acid-fast bacilli in a slit skin smear

Reference: International textbook of leprosy, chapter 2.

questions.text: A peripheral nerve block was to be performed for the longest cutaneous nerve of the body. Which of the following could have been anesthetized?
questions.solution:
Saphenous nerve is the longest cutaneous nerve of the body.

  • The saphenous nerve (L3, L4) arises in the proximal aspect of the anterior thigh from the posterior division of the femoral nerve.
  • It then descends through the femoral triangle, running laterally to the femoral artery.
  • The saphenous nerve then enters the adductor canal, also called Hunter' canal, where it crosses the femoral artery anteriorly to lie medial to it.
  • Upon exiting the adductor canal, the nerve then descends behind the sartorius muscle and pierces the fascia lata between the tendons of the sartorius and gracilis muscles and becomes subcutaneous, to supply the skin over the anterior surface of the patella.
  • The saphenous nerve continues to descend down the medial (tibial) aspect of the leg, running alongside the greater saphenous vein.
  • The nerve communicates with the medial branch of the superficial branch of the common fibular nerve.
  • Both of these nerves then supply sensation to the anterior surface of the leg.

Reference: BD Chaurasia's Human Anatomy, regional and applied, 8thedition, volume 2, page 148.

choices.text: On single-stranded DNA in the cytoplasm
On circular DNA in the mitochondrion
On double-stranded DNA in the nucleus
On linear DNA in the mitochondrion

questions.text: Given the pattern of inheritance shown in the pedigree, where might you find the disease gene in question?
questions.solution:
The pedigree illustrates the maternal inheritance of a mitochondrial gene. The mitochondrial genome is comprised of circular DNA that encodes genes important for energy and metabolism.

Because mitochondria are present in the maternal egg but are lost in the sperm, mitochondrial genes are inherited almost exclusively from the maternal side. As mitochondria are involved with energy production, mitochondrial disease often leads to problems with metabolism.

Examples of Mitochondrial Inheritance are:

  • Mitochondrial myopathy
  • Diabetes mellitus and deafness (DAD)
  • Leber's hereditary optic neuropathy (LHON)
  • Leigh syndrome, subacute necrotizing encephalomyelopathy
  • Neuropathy, ataxia, retinitis pigmentosa, and ptosis (NARP)
  • Myoneurogenic gastrointestinal encephalopathy (MNGIE)

Reference: Textbook of Biochemistry for Medical Students, by DM Vasudevan, 9th Edition

choices.text: Hemodynamic instability despite vigorous resuscitation (>6-unit transfusion)
Continued slow bleeding with a transfusion requirement exceeding 2 units/ day
Recurrent hemorrhage after initial stabilization (with up to two attempts at obtaining endoscopic hemostasis)

questions.text: All of the following are indications for surgery in gastrointestinal hemorrhage except?
questions.solution:
Indications for surgery in gastrointestinal hemorrhage -

  • Hemodynamic instabilitydespite vigorous resuscitation (>6-unit transfusion).
  • Failure of endoscopic techniques to arrest hemorrhage.
  • Continued slow bleeding with a transfusion requirement exceeding 3 units/ day.
  • Recurrent hemorrhageafter initial stabilization (with up to two attempts at obtaining endoscopic hemostasis).
  • Shockassociated withrecurrenthemorrhage

Reference: Sabiston 21stedition, Ch 47, Pg No 1155.

questions.text: Pneumoretinopexy is an outpatient procedure in which retinal detachment is sealed with air insufflation. Which of the following gas is used in pneumatic retinopexy?
questions.solution:
Pneumatic retinopexyis an outpatient procedure in which an intravitreal gas bubble together with cryotherapy or laser is used to seal a retinal break and reattach the retina without scleral buckling.

The most frequently used gases are sulfur hexafluoride (SF6)and the longer-acting perfluoropropane (C3F8).

The procedure is usually reserved for the treatment of uncomplicated retinal detachmentwith a small retinal break or a cluster of breaks extending over an area of less than two clock hours in the upper two-thirds of the peripheral retina.

It has the advantage of being a relatively quick, minimally invasive, 'office-based' procedure. However, success rates are usually worse thanthose achievable with conventional scleral buckling.

Reference: Kanski 7/e, p. 715.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of the primary olfactory cortex?
questions.solution:
The orbitofrontal cortex is generally considered to be the secondary olfactory cortex, not the primary olfactory cortex, as it does not receive olfactory bulb afferents. It does connect reciprocally with the major elements of the primary olfactory cortex, with some of these connections occurring through the thalamus.

The primary olfactory cortex is comprised of -

  • Anterior olfactory nucleus (AON)
  • Piriform cortex
  • Olfactory tubercle
  • Entorhinal area
  • Periamygdaloid cortex
  • Corticomedial amygdala.

Reference: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition chapter no 27 Olfaction and Gustation page no 562.

questions.text: A 29-year-old male presents with a complaint of infertility. His medical history is significant for recurrent respiratory infections since he was a child. Semen analysis is ordered and reveals significantly reduced sperm motility. To confirm the suspected diagnosis, the physician orders a chest radiograph, which is shown in the image. Which of the following is the cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
This patient's presentation is consistent with Kartagener's syndrome, which is caused by immotile cilia resulting from a dynein arm defect.

The presentation of primary ciliary dyskinesia involves chronic respiratory infections, including chronic sinusitis and bronchiectasis, as well as male infertility. The presence of situs inversusis required for the diagnosis of Kartagener's syndrome; 50% of patients with primary cilia dyskinesia have situs inversus and therefore qualify for this diagnosis. This condition demonstrates autosomalrecessiveinheritance.

Chest radiograph showing situs inversus (note the dextrocardia and tram-tracking in the lower lung lobes indicative of bronchiectasis), a component of Kartagener syndrome.

Other Options:

Option A: Chediak-Higashi syndrome, which presents with recurrent pyogenic infections, partial albinism, and peripheral neuropathy, is caused by a microtubule polymerization defect.

Option B: Kinesin, the molecular motor protein that mediates anterograde transport, is not affected in Kartagener's syndrome.

Option C: Sphingomyelinase is deficient in Niemann-Pick disease, which presents with hepatosplenomegaly, anemia, cherry red spot macula, failure to thrive, and neurodegeneration.

Reference: Textbook of Biochemistry for Medical Students, by DM Vasudevan, 9th Edition.

choices.text: Stop the medication, followed by an urgent anomaly scan.
Stop the medication, followed by a routine anomaly scan.
Switch benzoyl peroxide to topical tretinoin.

questions.text: A 21-year-old patient presents to the clinic for a follow-up. She has been using benzoyl peroxide for acne with mild benefit, which was prescribed six months ago. She mentions that she is four months pregnant and expecting a baby girl. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
• The Food & Drug Administration (FDA) classifies benzoyl peroxide as pregnancy risk category C.
  • No adequate studies have been conducted in humans to show whether benzoyl peroxide can cause harm to the mother or the fetus.
  • However, because of its low systemic absorption, topical benzoyl peroxide application is generally considered safe during pregnancy.

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology, 9thedition chapter 31.

questions.text: A 3-month-old boy has irritability, feeding difficulties, and frequent episodes of spasticity. Physical examination reveals stunted growth, developmental delay, and hyperreflexia. An ophthalmologist performs a fundus examination, which reveals thinning of the nerve fiber layer of the retina. An enzymatic study notes the deficiency of galactocerebrosidase. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Krabbe diseaseis an autosomal recessivelysosomal storage disease caused by a deficiency of the enzyme galactocerebrosidase, which leads to the accumulation of galactocerebroside and psychosine.

Typical findings in patients with Krabbe disease include peripheral neuropathy, hyperreflexia, optic atrophy, and developmental delay.

Histology of brain white matter reveals the presence of globoid cells, which are large, multinucleated cells that contain PAS-positive inclusions.

Krabbe disease causes optic atrophy, caused by damage to the retinal ganglion cell axons that comprise the optic nerve, and is seen on funduscopic examination as a pale optic nerve.

Treatment for Krabbe disease focuses on supportive care.

Other Options:

Option A: Fabry diseaseis an X-linked recessive disease that is caused by a deficiency of alpha-galactosidase A, leading to the accumulation of ceramide trihexoside. Typical early-stage findings include peripheral neuropathy, angiokeratomas, and hypohidrosis, while late-stage findings include progressive renal failure and cardiovascular disease.

Option B: Gaucher diseaseis an autosomal recessive disease that is caused by a deficiency of glucocerebrosidase, leading to the accumulation of glucocerebroside. Typical findings include hepatosplenomegaly, pancytopenia, osteoporosis, avascular necrosis of the femur, and bone crises.

Option D: Niemann-Pick diseaseis an autosomal recessive disease that is caused by a deficiency of sphingomyelinase, leading to the accumulation of sphingomyelin. Typical findings include progressive neurodegeneration, hepatosplenomegaly, foam cells, and a cherry-red spot on the macula (caused by lipid accumulation in retinal ganglion cells leading to the appearance of a white, pale retina).

Reference: Textbook of Biochemistry for Medical Students, by DM Vasudevan, 9th Edition.

choices.text: Is useful in treating malignant hyperthermia

questions.text: Pick the correct statement in regards to Dantrolene sodium.
questions.solution:
• Dantrolene(1-10 mg/kg i.v.) is used in the treatment of malignant hyperthermia.
  • It inhibits muscle contraction by preventing calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum by inhibiting the ryanodine receptor.
  • It is not an opiate antagonist although it may have some GABA-related effects.
  • It has minimal respiratory effects.

Reference: Sasada M, Smith S. Drugs in Anaesthesia and Intensive Care, 2nd Edn. Oxford University Press, 1997.
