choices.text: Esophagitis is the most common cause of non-variceal haemorrhage in the esophagus
Superficial mucosal ulcerations generally bleed acutely and are more commonly manifested as anemia or guaiac-positive stools
Crohn's disease is one of the causes of esophageal haemorrhage
Patient suffering from the infectious cause of esophagitis seldom require surgical management

questions.text: All of the following regarding esophagitis is true except?
questions.solution:
The esophagus is an infrequent site of non-variceal hemorrhage. When it does occur, it is most commonlythe result of esophagitis.

Esophageal inflammation secondary to repeated exposure of the esophageal mucosa to the acidic gastric secretions in gastroesophageal reflux disease leads to an inflammatory response that can result in chronic blood loss.

Ulcerationmay accompany this, but the superficialmucosal ulcerations generally do not bleed acutelyand are more commonly manifested as anemia or guaiac-positive stools.

Various infectious agentsmay also cause esophagitis, particularly in the immune-compromised host. With infection, hemorrhage can occasionally be massive.

Other causes of esophageal bleeding include medications, Crohn's disease, and radiation.

Treatment of esophagitis -

  • Acid suppressive therapy.
  • Endoscopiccontrol of the hemorrhage.
  • In patients with an infectious cause, targeted therapyis appropriate. Surgery is seldom necessary.

Reference: Sabiston 21stedition, Ch 47, Pg No 1156.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with a two-day history of rash on his abdomen. He is up to date with his vaccination schedule. On examination, a unilateral vesicular rash is present on the left side of the abdomen that involves a single dermatome. Which of the following is the most likely complication?
questions.solution:
This vesicular rash involving a single dermatome gives a diagnosis of herpes zosterinfection.

  • The most likely complication of herpes zoster is persistent pain, which is known as post-herpetic neuralgia.
  • Herpes zoster is the reactivationof the varicella-zoster virus that has been latent in the dorsal root ganglion.
  • Post-herpetic neuralgia commonly occurs in elderly patients. When the lesions have crusted, they may use topical capsaicin, lidocaine, and prilocaine cream.
  • Recurrent skin rash can occur in patients who are immunocompromised.

Splenomegaly and jaundice are not complications of herpes zoster infection.

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology, 9thedition chapter 25, page number 25-28.

questions.text: Restriction endonuclease will act on which of the following?
questions.solution:
Restriction endonuclease will act on AAGCTT.

Restriction endonucleaseact and cleave at the site of a palindromic sequence, such as

5'-- AAGCTT -3'

3'-- TTCGAA -5'

A palindromic sequence is a sequence that reads the same forwards and backward.

Reference: Textbook of Biochemistry for Medical Students, by DM Vasudevan, 9th Edition, Page No. 643

questions.text: A 27-year-old HIV-positive female gave birth to a 3.2 kg girl. The obstetrician is worried that the child may have been infected by HIV. Which of the following assays would a hospital use to detect the genetic material of HIV if the child had been infected?
questions.solution:
Polymerase chain reaction(PCR) is the only technique that would allow for the detection of genetic materialfrom HIV. PCR will amplify an RNA or DNA sequence by using specific primers that flank the region of interest.

PCR amplifies RNA or DNA through the use of a heat-resistant Taq polymeraseand repeated cycles of denaturation, annealing, and replication.

  • First, a set of DNA primers are synthesized that flank the RNA or DNA region of interest.
  • A solution is then prepared that contains the Taq polymerase, primers, RNA or DNA sample, deoxyribonucleotides, and buffer.
  • The solution is heated to denature the RNA or DNA sample; it is then cooled to allow the primers to anneal to the 3' ends of each single strand.
  • The Taq polymerase then binds and extends from the primer in the 5' direction.
  • The solution is heated again to denature the RNA or DNA strands and the cycle is repeated many more times to amplify the sequence of interest, in this case, the genetic material of HIV.

Maternal antibodies usually cross the placenta during pregnancy, therefore any test that detects antibodies to HIV could give a false positive reading even if the child has not been infected with HIV.

Other Options:

Option A: ELISA (enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay) is a laboratory test that uses antibodies to detect specific antigens and is often the first step in screening for HIV in adults. It can detect antibodies against HIV, but not the genetic material.

Option B: Western blot is a laboratory technique that combines electrophoresis of proteins and subsequent fragment detection using protein-specific antibodies. It is commonly used as a confirmatory test following a positive ELISA.

Option C: Rapid HIV antibody test uses a similar mechanism as ELISA and detects antibodies to HIV in the saliva.

Reference:Textbook of Biochemistry for Medical Students, by DM Vasudevan, 9th Edition, Page No. 643.

questions.text: The shortest incubation period among sexually transmitted infections is of:
questions.solution:
• Gonococcal urethritis ---- 1 to 5 days
  • Non- Gonococcal urethritis----- 1 week to 5 weeks
  • Syphilis--- 9 to 90 days
  • Granuloma inguinale--- 7 to days

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology, 9thedition chapter 4.1

questions.text: The 3'-terminal sequence of tRNA molecule is CCA. Which of the following best describes the function of this site?
questions.solution:
The tRNAis typically 75-90 nucleotides in length and has a secondary structure that resembles a cloverleafwith three stem-loop motifs.

The 5'-CCA-3' terminal end(the acceptor stem), which is present in both eukaryotic and prokaryotic tRNA, covalently binds to an amino acid in an ATP-dependent reaction catalyzed by aminoacyl-tRNA synthetase. This reaction creates a charged tRNA molecule whose amino acid can then be incorporated into the growing peptide chain by the ribosome. Each amino acid has a specific aminoacyl-tRNA synthetase.


Other Options:

Option A: Aminoacyl-tRNA synthetase is recognized by the D-arm of tRNA, named so because it contains the specially modified uracil residue dihydrouridine. This arm also helps stabilize the spatial structure of the tRNA molecule.

Option B: Protection of RNA molecules from degradation is accomplished by the addition of a 3' poly-A tail. However, this is a feature of mRNA, not tRNA.

Option C: The peptidyl site (P site) is contained within the ribosome; binding to this site involves the T-arm (tether arm) of tRNA, which is located in the third stem loop close to the 3' end. After aminoacyl-tRNA binds to the aminoacyl site (A site), catalytic rRNA (ribozyme) links the elongating polypeptide chain to the incoming amino acid; the ribosome then shifts by 3 nucleotides in the 3' direction, which moves the growing peptidyl tRNA to the P site.

Reference: Textbook of Biochemistry for Medical Students, by DM Vasudevan, 9th Edition, Page Number 616.

choices.text: Surgical removal only with no medical treatment.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man from India presents with symptoms of epistaxis and nasal obstruction. Physical examination discloses a friable, painless, polypoid growth at the nasal vestibule. The treatment for the most likely cause of these findings includes
questions.solution:
This patient most likely has Rhinosporidiosis.

Rhinosporidiosis is a chronic, granulomatous disease caused by the fungal pathogen Rhinosporidium seeberi. It primarily affects the mucosal tissues of the nasal cavity, but can also involve the conjunctiva, mouth, and genital tract. The condition is most commonly found in tropical and subtropical regions and is usually diagnosed in middle-aged or older adults.

Symptoms of rhinosporidiosis can include a mass or growth in the nose, persistent nasal discharge, and occasional bleeding from the affected area. In some cases, there may also be associated symptoms such as congestion, headache, and reduced sense of smell.

Diagnosis of rhinosporidiosis is typically made through examination of tissue samples obtained via biopsy. Surgical excision is the preferred treatment. No effective medical treatment as yet exists. The prognosis is generally good, although in some cases the disease may recur after treatment.

Reference: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition chapter no 30 Etiology of Infectious Diseases of the Upper Respiratory Tract page no 651.

questions.text: Ketamine may
questions.solution:
Ketamineis a phencyclidine derivativepresented as a racemic mixture.

  • It increases heart rate, blood pressure, and catecholaminelevels by a generalized increase in CNS activity.
  • Muscle tone is increasedand it may lead to generalized muscle rigidity.
  • Problems with ketamine include unpleasant dreams, hallucinations, emergence delirium,and pain on injection. It increases uterine tone.

Reference: Pinnock CA, Lin ES, Smith T. Fundamentals of Anaesthesia, 2nd Edn. Greenwich Medical Media Ltd, 2003, Section 3: Chapter 6.

choices.text: Carpopedal spasm induced by sphygmomanometer inflation
Holosystolic murmur heard at the apex with radiation to the axilla
Symptoms may develop secondary to left ventricular outflow tract obstruction

questions.text: An 8-year-old child with 'elfin' facial features is very friendly with strangers. He has a history of mild mental retardation, and a hemizygous deletion on chromosome 7q11.23, which includes a portion of the elastin gene. Which of the following is most likely true in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical presentation and genetic mutation are highly suggestive of Williams syndrome(WS).

  • WS is due to an autosomal dominantdeletion in chromosome 7q11.23that includes a region of the elastin gene.
  • These patients usually present with distinctive facies that is characterized as 'elfin'or 'pixie-like.'
  • Mental retardation, growth deficiency, and unique personality traits, which include friendliness, empathy, anxiety, and attention deficit disorder, are seen in patients with WS.
  • Supravalvular aortic stenosisis commonly seen in these patients. Thus, patients with WS should be evaluated for elastin arteriopathy.
  • Hypercalcemiaof idiopathic etiology can be present, thus Vitamin D should be avoided with monitoring of calcium intake.

Other Options:

Option A: This suggests hypocalcemia. Patients with WS are more likely to have hypercalcemia than hypocalcemia.

Option B: Due to the hypercalcemia that can be found in these patients, Vitamin D supplementation is to be avoided.

Option C: This describes mitral regurgitation. Patients with WS commonly present with elastin arteriopathies, most commonly being supravalvular aortic stenosis, not mitral regurgitation.

Reference: Medical Genetics by Jorde, Carey, and Bamshad, Fifth Edition, Page Number 240.

questions.text: In 2021 the national mean score on the NEET-PG exam was 350 with a standard deviation of 35. Assuming that the scores for 15,000 people follow a normal distribution, approximately how many students scored above the mean but below 385?
questions.solution:
Standard deviation (SD) is a measure of the dispersion from the average.

  • 68% of values lie within 1 SD of the mean in either direction.
  • 95% lie within 2 SDs from the mean.
  • 7% lie within 3 SDs from the mean.

Although these values can be calculated, for exam purposes these numbers should be memorized. Since 68% of students fall within 1 SD in either direction from the mean, approximately 34% of students are between the mean (350) and the mean + 1 SD (350+35 = 385).

34% multiplied by the total number of students (15,000) equals 5,100.

Reference: Textbook of Preventive & Social Medicine, by K. Park, 26th Edition, Page Number 60.

choices.text: Early dumping occurs within 30 minutes of a meal and is a result of carbohydrates being delivered rapidly into the proximal intestine.
Late dumping occurs 1 to 3 hrs after a meal due to the rapid passage of high osmolarity food from the stomach into the small intestine.
The symptoms associated with early dumping syndrome appear to be secondary to the release of several humoral agents, such as serotonin, bradykinin-like substances, neurotensin, and enteroglucagon
Anticholinergics are the best-studied medication for dumping syndrome and can be very effective

questions.text: Which of the following is a correct statement regarding Dumping syndrome?
questions.solution:
Option a) Early dumping occurs within 30 minutes of a meal and is a result of the rapid passage of high osmolarity food from the stomach into the small intestine.

Option b) Late dumping occurs 1 to 3 hours after a meal and is less common. The basic defect of late dumping is also rapid gastric emptying; however, it is related specifically to carbohydrates being delivered rapidly into the proximal intestine

Option c) is correct. The symptoms associated with early dumping syndrome appear to be secondary to the release of several humoral agents, such as serotonin, bradykinin-like substances, neurotensin, and enteroglucagon. Dietary measures are usually sufficient to treat most patients.

Option d) Octreotideis the best-studied medication for dumping syndrome and can be very effective. However, the peptides are expensive and are thus not considered first-line treatment typically.

Reference: Sabiston 21stedition, Pg No 1217.

questions.text: The following lesion is characteristic of
questions.solution:
The image shows interosseous membrane ossification which is characteristic of fluorosis.

  • Fluorosis stimulates osteoblastic activity.
  • Fluorapatite crystals are laid down in bone and these are unusually resistant to secondary osteoclastic resorption.
  • This leads to calcium retention, osteosclerosis, and osteophytosis.
  • Ossification of ligaments and fascial attachmentsis characteristic.

Reference: Apley's system of orthopaedics and fracture page no 143.

choices.text: Stratum spinosum is also called stratum germinativum
Stratum basale also called prickle cell layer
Intraepidermal intercellular connections are called desmosome
The maximum concentration of desmosomes are present in the corneum layer

questions.text: You are in the histology class. You have been taught the structure of the skin. Based on that knowledge answer the following question. Which among the given statements is true?
questions.solution:
Intraepidermal intercellular connection are called desmosomes.

Stratum basale is also called as stratum germinativum.

Stratum spinosum is also called as prickle cell layer.

The maximum concentration of desmosomes are present in stratum spinosum

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology 9thedition chapter 3

choices.text: The characteristic Negri bodies are found in Purkinje cell of the cerebellum and hippocampus.
Infection spreads more commonly by dog bites than by bats and raccoons.
Bullet-shaped virus is a causative organism.

questions.text: A body of a 24-year-old male was received for an autopsy. The presence of 'Negri bodies' was determined as shown in the image. Before death, the patient had a history of dog bite and showed symptoms like increased salivation, drooling mental confusion, and aggressiveness. Which of the following is false about the causative organism?
questions.solution:
This is a case of rabies.

The infection spreads more commonly from bats, raccoons, and skunk bitesthan from dog bites.

  • Rabies virus belongs to the Rhabdoviridae
  • It is a bullet-shaped
  • Negri bodiesare cytoplasmic inclusion bodies that are characteristic of rabies infection. They are most commonly found in Purkinje cells of the cerebellum and in hippocampal neurons.
  • Rabies has a long incubation periodbefore symptoms onset.
  • The virus travels to the central nervous system by migrating in a retrograde fashionvia nerve axons after binding to Ach receptors.
  • Disease first starts with fever, then follows with agitation, photophobia, hydrophobia, hypersalivation, and lastly with paralysis, coma, and death.
  • Aerosoltransmission in Bat caves is also possible.

Post-exposure prophylaxisis wound cleaning plus immunization with killed vaccine and rabies immunoglobulin. This is an example of passive active immunity.

Reference: USMLE First Aid, Page 171.

questions.text: A newlywed couple comes to your office for genetic counseling. Both potential parents are known to be carriers of the same Cystic Fibrosis (CF) mutation. What is the probability that at least one of their next three children will have CF if they are all single births?
questions.solution:
The probability of all events occurring is the product of the probabilities of each event occurring independently.

The probability of at least 1 event turning out differently is thus (1 - the probability of all events being the same). In this case, the probability is 37/64.

Cystic Fibrosis (CF) is an autosomal recessive trait, and as such, the likelihood of two carriers having an affected child is 1/4.

Each successive child is an independent event so long as the CF status of other births has no bearing on its own status. This is the case for single births and fraternal twins but is not the case for identical twins.

Because the probability of having an unaffected child (either wild type or carrier) is 3/4, the probability of having three unaffected children is (3/4)*(3/4)*(3/4) = 27/64.

The probability of having at least 1 child with CF is thus 1-27/64 = 37/64.

Reference: Medical Genetics by Jorde, Carey and Bamshad, Fifth Edition, Page Number 60.

questions.text: A patient complaints of fatigue, weakness, constipation, decreased appetite, and intermittent flank pain. Physical examination shows mild tenderness bilaterally in the costovertebral areas. His serum calcium is 11.2mg/dL, phosphorus is 2.5mg/dL, and PTH is 230 pg/mL. Which of the following steps in vitamin D metabolism is most likely increased?
questions.solution:
This patient's symptoms (fatigue, weakness, constipation, decreased appetite, and intermittent flank pain, likely due to kidney stones) and laboratory abnormalities (increased calcium and PTH, decreased phosphorus) are consistent with primary hyperparathyroidism.

In primary hyperparathyroidism, excess PTHinduces the expression of 1-alpha-hydroxylasein the proximal convoluted tubule cells of the kidney, which leads to increased conversion of 25-hydroxycholecalciferol into its metabolically active form1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol.

25-hydroxycholecalciferol is produced in the liver via hydroxylation of cholecalciferol, which has been previously synthesized in the skin under the influence of sunlight from 7-dehydrocholesterol.

Reference: Textbook of Biochemistry for Medical Students, by DM Vasudevan, 9th Edition, Page Number 487.

questions.text: You're an orthopedic intern on OP duty today. A patient presents with pain in the knee associated with swelling and stiffness. This worsens while putting pressure on the joint. You think of it as a case of a meniscal tear. In case of a meniscal tear repair, which zone do you think heals best?
questions.solution:
In case of a meniscal tear, the red zone heals the best due to its rich blood supply.



The menisci are supplied by peri meniscal blood vessels from superior and inferior branches of the genicular medial and lateral vessels.

The Meniscus is divided into three zones.

  • The white-white zone(more than 5 mmfrom the periphery) is the central zone, which has no blood supply at all. Tears in this zone cannot be repaired.
  • The Red-White zone(within 3 mm to 5 mmfrom the periphery) is the mid-zone of the Meniscus which has a minimalblood supply. Tears in this zone may be repaired depending on the type of tear and duration since the injury.
  • Red-Red Zone(within 3 mmof the periphery) is the peripheral zone which is at the meniscocapsular junctionand is rich in blood supply. Tears in this zone may be repaired with good results.

Reference: Beynnon BD, et al. (2010). Meniscal injuries. In JC DeLee et al., eds., DeLee and Drez's Orthopaedic Sports Medicine: Principles and Practice, 3rd ed., vol. 2 pp. 1596-1623. Philadelphia: Saunders Elsevier.

choices.text: Ingestion of food contaminated with sporulated oocyst

questions.text: Which of the following is not a mode of transmission for Toxoplasma gondii?
questions.solution:
T.gondii is unique among the protozoa as all the three morphological forms can transmit the infection. Transmission to man occurs by

  • Ingestion of sporulated oocysts(infective form) from contaminated soil, food, or water (most common route).
  • Ingestion of tissue cyst containing Bradyzoites(infective form) from undercooked meat.
  • By blood transfusion, needle stick Injuries, organ transplantation, transplacental transmission, or laboratory accidents. Tachyzoitesare the infective form.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Panikers Textbook of Microbiology third edition, pg no 688.

choices.text: Cofactor for the enzyme that hydroxylates proline and lysine
Forms a complex which cleaves pre-procollagen
Mediates the formation of the triple helix of procollagen

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presents to the healthcare provider with malaise and easy bruising. also, there is evidence of gum disease and several loose teeth. She has a deficiency of a water-soluble vitamin. What is the role of this vitamin in collagen synthesis?
questions.solution:
• Vitamin Cis an essential cofactor for the enzyme lysyl hydroxylase that hydroxylates proline and lysine.
  • Without hydroxyproline, collagen is less stable because of the lack of cross-linking between the collagen strands.
  • Vitamin C, ascorbic acid, or L-ascorbic acid, is a vitamin found in food and used as a dietary supplement.
  • Vitamin C is used to prevent and treat scurvy.

Reference: Harper's illustrated Biochemistry, 31stedition, page - 539.

questions.text: The woman is suspected to have acute viral hepatitis and is admitted. The management of this woman includes all of the following except-
questions.solution:
In acute viral hepatitis, only supportive care is needed.

  • IV fluids are given
  • As there is liver dysfunction- the patient is advised to have a high carbohydrate and low protein diet
  • Injection Vitamin K is given for synthesis of clotting factors.

Immediate termination of pregnancy is of no help.

Reference: Ian Donald's practical obstetric problems 8thedition, Page no 250.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman, Sarjoo comes to the physician for numbness and tingling in her legs. Her only medication is an OCPs. Her Hb is 10g/dL and her MCV is 76. Bone marrow biopsy shows erythroblasts with a ring of basophilic granules around the nucleus. This patient's condition is caused by the deficiency of a substrate that acts as a cofactor in which of the following steps of catecholamine synthesis?
questions.solution:
In a patient taking OCPs, clinical features of peripheral neuropathy (paresthesias, decreased sensation in the extremities) and sideroblastic anemia (microcytic hypochromic anemia with sideroblasts in the bone marrow) suggest a vitamin B6 deficiency.

DOPA decarboxylasecatalyzes the conversion of L-DOPA to dopaminein the presence of the cofactor pyridoxal phosphate(active form of vitamin B6), which also serves as a cofactor in multiple other reactions, such as cystathionine synthesis, heme synthesis, decarboxylation, and transamination reactions.

Clinical features of vitamin B6 deficiencyinclude glossitis, gingivostomatitis, peripheral neuropathy, and sideroblastic anemia, as observed in the patient.

Reference: Textbook of Biochemistry for Medical Students, by DM Vasudevan, 9th Edition, Page Number 502.

choices.text: Patients can easily be classified into perennial and seasonal categories.
Ancillary tests are infrequently employed to evaluate allergic patients.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the diagnosis of allergic rhinitis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis of allergic rhinitis relies on a careful history to identify the sensitizing antigen, both to establish the diagnosis and to institute the first treatment, avoidance.

Symptoms occurring in temporal relation to allergen exposure suggest sensitization but are not diagnostic.

With a classic history (eg, sneezing each fall), empiric therapy may provide the simplest approach. In less clear cases, allergy testing either by skin prick, intradermal or in vitro methods can identify allergens causing sensitization.

However, individuals can show evidence of sensitization by a positive skin test or elevated specific antibody levels in the serum without having evidence of clinical disease. This emphasizes the importance of good history in the evaluation of patients with suspected allergic disorders.

Ancillary testing is often employed to evaluate for complications of allergic rhinitis as well as related disorders such as sinusitis (computed tomography scans) and asthma (pulmonary function testing).

Endoscopy, although not always indicated, can be useful in evaluating for structural abnormalities (septal deviation), evidence of related diseases (sinusitis), and other nonallergic nasal disorders.

Reference: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition chapter no 32 Allergic Rhinitis page no 720.

questions.text: To test hormone levels in the fed state, the mice are given an oral glucose load and various hormones are measured in a blood sample. Researchers are most interested in the hormone whose blood levels track evenly with C-peptide levels. The hormone the researchers are most interested in is responsible for which of the following actions in the body?
questions.solution:
Insulin and C-peptide are co-secreted equally, therefore insulin levels are expected to track with C-peptide levels.

Insulin is a hormone released in the fed state in response to increased blood glucose. During the synthesis of insulin, C-peptide is exocytosed with insulin equally, and thus levels of both are the same in the blood. Insulin has many effects including as an anabolic hormone. It, therefore, causes increased glycogen synthesis, fatty acid synthesis, protein synthesis, and glucose uptake into fat, muscle, and liver.

Other Options:

Option B: Fatty acid breakdown (lipolysis) is induced by glucagon.

Option C: Protein anabolism, not protein catabolism, is promoted by insulin.

Option D: Ketogenesis via lipolysis and fatty acid breakdown is promoted by glucagon.

Reference:Textbook of Biochemistry for Medical Students, by DM Vasudevan, 9th Edition, Page Number 230.

questions.text: Proteins are bound to a regulatory molecule that usually marks them for degradation. The regulatory molecule in question is most likely which of the following?
questions.solution:
Tagging with ubiquitin marks proteins for degradation by the ubiquitin-proteasome system (UPS).

Dysfunction of the UPS is implicated in various neurodegenerative brain diseases, including frontotemporal dementia, Alzheimer's disease, Parkinson's disease, and Huntington's disease.


Other Options:

Option A: Chaperone proteins assist in the molecular assembly and folding of other proteins. Defects or losses of chaperone proteins can lead to protein misfolding and contribute to neurodegeneration as seen in this patient. However, chaperone proteins do not mark other proteins for degradation.

Option B: Clathrin is a protein that coats vesicles and assists in vesicular endocytosis and trafficking. Although dysfunction of clathrin-mediated endocytosis is hypothesized to be involved in the development of some neurodegenerative brain diseases, clathrin does not mark protein targets for degradation.

Option C: Cyclins control the cell cycle and transitions between cell cycle phases. Cyclin dysfunction can lead to uncontrolled cell division that causes malignancy. Cyclins do not mark protein targets for degradation.

Reference: Textbook of Biochemistry for Medical Students, by DM Vasudevan, 9th Edition, Page Number 28.

questions.text: Patients presenting with genital ulcers to the STD clinic were subjected to the VDRL test. Those testing positive were sent for FT-ABS testing for syphilis. In such a combination of screening, what will happen to the determinants of screening?
questions.solution:
When one screening test is done, (VDRL in this case) and the next is done following a positive/negative result in the first (here, FTA-ABS for a positive VDRL), it is known as testing in series.

Testing in parallel is when all screening tests are employed at the same time.

In testing in series,

  • Sensitivity decreases
  • Specificity increases
  • PPV increases
  • NPV decreases

Reference: Textbook of Preventive & Social Medicine, by K. Park, 26th Edition, Page Number 150.

choices.text: EM is best regarded as a self-limiting
It is a hypersensitivity reaction most commonly to drugs or infection
Herpes simplex virus is the most common cause

questions.text: All of the following statements about erythema multiforme (EM) are true except
questions.solution:
Erythema multiforme (EM) is best regarded as a self-limiting cytotoxic dermatitis resulting

from cell-mediated hypersensitivity most commonly to drugs or infection.

Common causes include-

  • Infections - Herpes simplex virus > Mycoplasma pneumoniae infection
  • Drug intake - sulfa drugs, phenytoin, penicillin
  • EM can also follow vaccinations, radiation therapy, and exposure to environmental toxins, including the oleoresin in poison ivy.

It presents clinically with a spectrum of macular, papular, or urticarial lesions, as well as the classic acral iris or 'target lesions'.

Reference - Rooks textbook of dermatology 9th edition 47.6.

choices.text: Condensation of acetyl-CoA with oxaloacetate to form citrate

questions.text: A 54-year-old chronic alcoholic male is admitted with ataxia, ophthalmoplegia, and altered mental status. Which reaction below is likely impaired in this man?
questions.solution:
This man with alcoholism has Wernicke's encephalopathy from thiamine deficiency.

Thiamine is a necessary cofactor for the enzyme a-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase, which is involved in the conversion of a-ketoglutarate into succinyl CoA.

Thiamine deficiency is common in alcoholism and those with malabsorption syndromes. If a thiamine-deficient patient is given a glucose load, the demands of the citric acid cycle, specifically a-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase, will cause the patient's thiamine levels to drop further.

Wernicke's encephalopathy results from low thiamine and is recognized by the triad of ACE: Ataxia, Confusion, and abnormal Eye movements. It usually resolves with the administration of thiamine.

Reference: Textbook of Biochemistry for Medical Students, by DM Vasudevan, 9th Edition, Page Number 334.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male has undergone resection of the distal ileum due to a malignancy. This patient is predisposed to form which types of stones?
questions.solution:
Hyperoxaluria may be seen in patients who have undergone small bowel resection, particularly the terminal ileum.

Resection of the terminal ileum can result in an increase in unabsorbed fatty acids and bile salts which undergo saponification by binding with calcium in the bowel.

The increase in unbound oxalate is absorbed by the large intestine and subsequently excreted in the urine, favoring the formation of calcium oxalate stones.

Reference - Sabistion 21st edition, Pg No 1762.

questions.text: Injecting cytotoxic T cells into the cell culture of one of the samples causes the tissue cells to undergo apoptosis. Apoptosis is most likely due to the secretion of which of the following substances in this case?
questions.solution:
Cytotoxic T cells induce apoptosis via an extrinsic signaling pathway.

  • Cytotoxic T cells and natural killer cells recognize target cells (most commonly virally infected and malignant cells) via MHC class I antigen presentation.
  • This induces activation of the extrinsic apoptotic pathway via the release of cytotoxic proteins, including granzymes (especially granzyme B) and perforins.
  • Perforins cause pores to form in the membrane of cells, which enable granzymes to enter the cytoplasm.
  • Granzyme B then activates executioner caspases (especially caspase-3), which cleave many substrates, causing the degradation of cellular components.
  • Finally, the degraded abnormal target cell (apoptotic cell) can be removed via macrophage phagocytosis.

Reference: Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas and Aster, 10th Edition, Page Number 31.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman complains of longstanding pain during activities in which her arms are held above her head, as well as at night when she lies on the affected side. Physical examination reveals a painful arc. Painful arc syndrome is seen in all except
questions.solution:
The partial tear of the supraspinatus tendon is responsible for painful arc syndrome rather than a complete tear.

Painful arc syndrome also known as shoulder impingement syndrome is a clinical syndrome in which soft tissues become painfully entrapped in the area of the shoulder joint. This arises because of the repetitive rubbing of the supraspinatus tendon under the coracoacromial arch. Patients report pain on elevating the arm between 70° and 120°.

Causes include

  • Subacromial impingement syndrome (external impingement)
  • Subcoracoid impingement
  • Postero-superior inner impingement
  • Antero-superior inner impingement
  • Minor tears of the supraspinatus tendon
  • Chronic supraspinatus tendinitis
  • Calcification of supraspinatus tendon
  • Fracture of greater tuberosity
  • Subacromial bursitis.

Treatment:

  • In the absence of major structural damage, conservative multimodal treatment for 3-6 months is the initial therapy of choice.
  • The treatment mainly addresses pain at first, then passive and active motion, and lastly strength and coordination.
  • Surgery is indicated if the symptoms fail to improve after 3 or more months of conservative treatment

Reference:-Impingement Syndrome of the Shoulder (nih.gov) • cal M, Akgun K, Birtane M, Karacan I, cal H, Tuzun F. Diagnostic values of clinical diagnostic tests in subacromial impingement syndrome. Annals of the rheumatic diseases. 2000 Jan 1;59(1):44-7.

choices.text: Cells with an increased nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio
Cellular debris and macrophages followed by cystic spaces and cavitation
Epithelioid cells surrounded by multinucleated giant cells and lymphocytes

questions.text: A HIV-positive man presents with fever, a productive cough streaked with blood, back pain, and night sweats. Which of the following characteristics would best describe the histology of a lung biopsy?
questions.solution:
This patient's presentation of a recurrence of fever, productive cough with blood, and night sweats in an immunocompromised host is suggestive of secondary (reactivation) tuberculosis.

Secondary tuberculosis histologically features caseating granulomas, which feature an area of central necrosis, surrounded by epithelioid cells, multinucleated giant cells, and lymphocytes.

Patients who experience a weakening of the immune system have a risk of reactivation of their latent tuberculosis infection. The infection may disseminate to the vertebral column to cause osteomyelitis (Pott's disease), which may be the cause of this patient's back pain. Infection with M. tuberculosis classically produces cavitary lesions in the lungs with a histological characteristic of caseating granulomas with central necrosis.

Other Options:

Option A: Cells with increased nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio are characteristic of dysplasia in a neoplastic progression of cells. Dysplasia is not characteristic of M. tuberculosis infection.

Option B: Cellular debris and macrophages followed by cystic spaces and cavitation are characteristic of liquefactive necrosis, which is seen in abscesses in bacterial infections as well as infarcts in the brain.

Option D: A macrophage filled with fungal microorganisms is characteristic of Histoplasma infection.

Reference: Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas, and Aster, 10th Edition, Page Number 31.

For treatment, doxycycline should be given for a week

The right kidney is bordered anterolaterally by the liver and the ascending colon.

The second portion of the duodenum may be encountered near the right renal vessels and thus sometimes requires anteromedial reflection, known as the Kocher maneuver, to achieve intraoperative vascular control during right renal surgery.
The left renal vein passes anteriorly to the aorta and receives drainage from the left gonadal vein, the left inferior adrenal vein, and a lumbar vein

questions.text: All of the following are correct regarding the anatomy of urogenital system except?
questions.solution:
The kidneys are bordered -

  • Posterolaterally by the quadratus lumborum muscle
  • Posteromedially by the psoas muscle.

Additionally, the diaphragm drapes across the posterior aspect of the superior pole of each kidney.

Reference: Schwartz 11e, Pg No. 1759.

choices.text: All children under 2 years of age to prevent 8 vaccine-preventable illnesses
All children and pregnant women under 2 years of age to prevent 7 vaccine-preventable illnesses
7 days- 7 coloured bedsheets in ESI hospitals
7 coloured tablets of iron in Anganwadis for different age groups

questions.text: The Indradhanush scheme targets which of the following?
questions.solution:
The Ministry of Health & Family Welfare has launched 'Mission Indradhanush', depicting seven colours of the rainbow, in December 2014, to fully immunize 90 percent of children who are either unvaccinated or partially vaccinated; those that have not been covered during the rounds of routine immunization for various reasons by 2020.

The diseases included under Mission Indradhanush include -

  • Tuberculosis
  • Polio
  • Hepatitis B
  • Diphtheria
  • Pertussis
  • Tetanus
  • Measles

Mission Indradhanush is to ensure full immunization with all available vaccines for children up to two years of age and pregnant women. The Government has identified 201 high-focus districts across 28 states in the country that have the highest number of partially immunized and unimmunized children.

Earlier the increase in full immunization coverage was 1% per year which has increased to 6.7% per year through the first two phases of Mission Indradhanush. Four phases of Mission Indradhanush have been conducted till August 2017 and more than 2.53 crore children and 68 lakh pregnant women have been vaccinated.

Intensified Mission Indradhanush includes 12 vaccine-preventable diseases.

Reference- https://www.esic.nic.in/Publications/Note_on_Launch.pdf

Park Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 26th edition - page 462.

choices.text: All of the cilia have an abnormal ultrastructure.
The mucociliary clearance time is lengthened.
Nitric oxide levels in the nose are less than in the chest.
Ciliary beat frequencies are around 14 Hz.

questions.text: In primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD),
questions.solution:
In primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD),

  • Tests of mucociliary clearance are either lengthened or impossible to measure. The normal range for a saccharin test would be 20 to 30 minutes.
  • Nitric oxide levels in the nose are usually higher than those in the chest as most of the gas is produced in the paranasal sinuses. Levels are significantly lower in both areas in primary ciliary dyskinesia, usually in single-figure parts per million from the chest and double figures from the nose and sinuses.
  • Ciliary beat frequency from the inferior turbinates is reduced below the normal range of 12 to 15 Hz or beats per second, uncoordinated or absent.
  • Both the ciliary ultrastructure and arrangement can be abnormal in PCD, but this does not necessarily affect all of the cilia.

Reference: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition chapter no 33 Acute and Chronic Nasal Disorders page no 744.

questions.text: An 11-year-old male has bilateral femur fractures after RTA. Post-mortem pathologic examination of abdominal tissues reveals white deposits containing calcium. Abnormal activity of which of the following proteins is most likely responsible for these deposits?
questions.solution:
This boy most likely has acute pancreatitis. Lipase release from pancreatitis can saponify abdominal fat resulting in fat necrosis.

Fat necrosis can be seen in the fat that has been damaged by trauma or by the release of lipases.

One common location where this occurs is in pancreatitis because dying pancreatic acinar cells may release pancreatic lipase into abdominal fat. Lipase breaks down triglycerides in fat and allows for the breakdown of products to undergo saponification. This is a process where lipids combine with calcium to produce chalky white deposits.

Other Options:

Option A: Non-specific deposition of immunoglobulin in the form of immune complexes can be seen in conditions such as polyarteritis nodosa and result in fibrinoid necrosis.

Option C: Increased activation of plasmin results in breakdown of clots and diffuse bleeding, which can be seen in certain toxins or overdoses of tissue plasminogen activator.

Option D: Abnormal activity of proteases can lead to digestion of connective tissue resulting in liquefactive necrosis in soft organs such as the brain.

Reference: Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas, and Aster, 10th Edition, Page Number 31.

choices.text: Pancytopenia and deep vein thrombosis with intermittent hemoglobinuria
Ventricular septal defect and facial dysmorphism with low T-lymphocyte count
Multiple opportunistic infections with decreased CD4 counts
Vesicular lesions with dermatomal distribution and dendritic corneal ulcers

questions.text: Cells in the sample are first labeled with fluorescent antibodies and then passed across a laser beam in a single file of particles. The light scatter and fluorescent intensity of the particles are plotted on a graph; this information is used to characterize the sample. This laboratory method would be most useful to establish the diagnosis of a patient with which of the following?
questions.solution:
The process described above is the procedure of flow cytometry, which is a laboratory technique used to count/sort cells after immune-labeling the antigen of interest.

Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) can present with pancytopenia, deep vein thrombosis, and intermittent hemoglobinuria. It usually results from impaired synthesis of the glycosylphosphatidylinositol anchor (GPI), which links cell surface proteins like CD55 and CD59 to the plasma membrane. These surface proteins are inhibitors of complement activation; their absence permits inappropriate complement-mediated destruction of cells.

Flow cytometry is used to detect the reduced expression of CD55 and CD59 on RBCs and confirm the diagnosis of PNH.

The image shows the result of Flow Cytometry in the form of scatter plots.


Reference: Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas and Aster, 10th Edition, Page Number 31.

choices.text: Pleomorphism of cells in the stratum corneum
Irreversible nuclear changes in the stratum basale
Full-thickness basal to apical cell polarity
Increased nuclear to cytoplasmic ratio in the stratum spinosum

questions.text: Which of the following histopathological features would be most consistent with carcinoma-in-situ?
questions.solution:
Neoplasia progresses along a predictable course from normal cellular morphology to the reversible changes of dysplasia and then to carcinoma in situ.

The formation of neoplasia starts with low-grade dysplasia, a reversible disordered growth of epithelium characterized by abnormally frequent mitotic figures, loss of cell orientation and uniformity, and nuclear changes. Carcinoma in situ is usually an irreversible severe (i.e., high-grade) dysplasia involving the entire thickness of the epithelium without penetration of the basement membrane.

Other Options:

Option A: Pleomorphism of cells in the stratum corneum is a feature of dysplasia, a still reversible process that can lead to carcinoma in situ. However, it is not only seen in cases that develop into carcinoma in situ.

Option C: A basal to apical cell polarity is a physiological feature of epithelial cells or epithelial cell layers, which line the body's surfaces and separate internal cavities from the outside environment. Loss of this polarity, however, is a sign of dysplasia, which may eventually lead to carcinoma in situ.

Option D: Increased nuclear to cytoplasmic ratio in the stratum spinosum is a feature of dysplasia, a still reversible process that can lead to carcinoma in situ. However, it is not only seen in cases that develop into carcinoma in situ.

Reference: Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas, and Aster, 10th Edition, Page Number 189.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with a history of falling on her outstretched arm. Immediate radiographs were taken. Identify the condition given in the X-RAY image?
questions.solution:
This a fracture involving distal radius with disruption of distal radial-ulnar joint with damage to the interosseous membrane and triangular fibro-cartilage component (TFCC).

This is Galeazzi Fracture.

Monteggia fracture is a fracture of the proximal ulna with dislocated radial head.

Greenstick fracture occurs in children where one cortex breaks and the other cortex bends.

Reference: Maheshwari ortho 5th edition page no 111.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with chronic spontaneous urticaria. You prescribe him second-line antihistamines. He visits you after 2 weeks, but there is no symptomatic relief. What will be your next best step?
questions.solution:
According to the treatment ladder of urticaria:

  • 1st step is to give antihistamines. If it does not respond,
  • 2nd step is to increase the dose of antihistamines to 4 times.

Reference - Rooks textbook of dermatology 9th edition chapter 42.

choices.text: Malignant growth in the suspensory ligament of cooper

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman presented with a feeling of a breast lump in her right breast for 3 months. She reports that it increased in size. There is no associated pain, tenderness, or local increase in temperature. On examination, the breast is fixed to the chest wall. FNAC reports revealed a malignant growth. The following changes were noted in the breast due to cancer. Which of the following is responsible for this change?
questions.solution:
The above images show retraction of skin and dimpling respectively, which are seen due to malignant infiltration in the suspensory ligament of cooper, which tethers breast to the underlying pectoral fascia. The breast becomes fixed and dimpling and puckering are seen. It is, however, not considered a sign of skin involvement in breast cancer staging.

Blockade of subdermal lymphatics causes a peau d'orange appearance, which is considered a sign of skin involvement.


Blockade of lactiferous ducts by malignant cells causes retraction of the nipple.


Reference: BD Chaurasia's human anatomy, regional and applied, 8th edition, volume-1 page 49.

questions.text: A 53-year-old man comes with a 3-month history of cough and progressively worsening difficulty walking up the stairs in his apartment. He has noticed that it is easier for him to climb the stairs after he has exercised. Muscle strength in the proximal lower extremity is initially 3/5 but increases to 5/5 after repeated muscle tapping. His Achilles reflex is 1+. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient's combination of smoking history, chronic cough, and weight loss is concerning for lung malignancy. Proximal muscle weakness that improves on repeated stimulation combined with hyporeflexia is suggestive of a paraneoplastic syndrome associated with lung cancer.

Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS), which is associated with small-cell lung cancer in two-thirds of cases, is caused by circulating autoantibodies that block presynaptic voltage-gated calcium channels (anti-VGCC antibodies) at the neuromuscular junction. This blockage impairs acetylcholine (ACh) release, which leads to reduced or absent deep tendon reflexes and proximal muscle weakness; the latter improves during exercise as repetitive nerve stimulation increases the amount of ACh in the synaptic cleft. Patients with LEMS may also develop symptoms of autonomic dysfunction such as a dry mouth, constipation, or impotence.


Reference: Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas, and Aster, 10th Edition, Page Number 189

choices.text: Sheep are the usual definitive host
Approximately 75% of the hydatid cysts are located in the right liver and are solitary.
Hydatid cysts are diagnosed more in men than women at an average age of about 45 years.

questions.text: A 55 yr old male came to you with chronic pain abdomen, nausea, and fever for the past 20 days. He has a history of a recent visit to Australia. Which of the following is true about the organism infecting the patient?
questions.solution:
This is a case of Hydatid disease or echinococcosis.

  • It is a zoonotic
  • Occurs primarily in sheep-grazing areas of the world but is common worldwide because the dog is a definitive host.
  • Echinococcosis is endemic in Mediterranean countries, the Middle East, Far East, South America, Australia, New Zealand, and east Africa.
  • Sheep are the usual intermediate host, but humans are an accidental intermediate host.
  • Hydatid cysts are diagnosed in equal numbers of men and women at an average age of about 45 years.
  • Approximately 75% of hydatid cysts are located in the right liver and are solitary.

Reference: Sabiston, 21e, page 1460.

questions.text: A 21-year-old female is found in a semi-conscious state. On initial evaluation, her blood glucose level is 23mg/dL. Her parents tell her that the patient is an athlete and was trying to gain weight recently. An evaluation of which of the following will help in establishing a diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The given clinical vignette strongly suggests hypoglycemia due to surreptitious use of exogenous insulin, characterized by a low C-peptide level.
  • Insulin abuse is a method for increasing muscle bulk and performance enhancement in athletes, although less common than anabolic steroid abuse.
  • Exogenous insulin does not contain C-peptide. Therefore the blood level of C-peptide will be low in such patients.
  • On the other hand, endogenous production of insulin will be characterized by high C-peptide levels in the blood.

Reference - Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 13th Edition Page no 984.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy was brought to the OPD by his mother with a complaint of pain and swelling in his leg for 3 weeks. There is no history of prior trauma. On examination, the temperature was 101 F, BP - 118/80, and HR 95/min. Investigations revealed raised TLC and neutrophils. X-ray shows laminated periosteal reaction on femur diaphysis. Which of the following is a false statement about the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above given clinical scenario is suggestive of Ewings sarcoma, and it is the most chemosensitive and radiosensitive bone tumor.

EWINGS SARCOMA:-

  • It is commonly seen in first to second decade of life.
  • More common in males
  • It usually presents with pain and swelling
  • Most common bone involved: Femur diaphysis
  • Its presentation mimics osteomyelitis
  • Fever is present
  • TLC, Neutrophils, and ESR are raised
  • CRP is positive
  • X-ray typically shows laminated periosteal reaction(onion peel appearance)
  • Karyotyping most commonly shows t(11:22) +ve.
  • It is the most chemosensitive and radiosensitive bone tumor.

Reference: -Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari and Mhaskar 5th edition, page no 243.

questions.text: A young man presented with bloody diarrhea, abdominal pain, and fever. Lab Investigations showed leukocytosis and stool microscopy revealed red blood cells and leucocytes. Darkfield microscopy showed bacteria having darting motility. Which of the following is a selective culture medium for this organism?
questions.solution:
Darting motility of the organism along with fever, bloody diarrhea, abdominal pain, and leucocytosis and RBCs in a fecal smear is suggestive of infection with Campylobacter jejuni.

Selective media for Campylobacter culture include -

  • Skirrow';s medium
  • Butzler's medium
  • Campy-BAP media

The transport medium used for Campylobacter is the Cary- Blair medium.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Panikers Textbook of Microbiology, Tenth edition pg no 406.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male presents with fatigue over the past 6 months and splenomegaly. A bone marrow aspiration is performed and a slide is shown. Cytogenetic workup reveals the presence of a translocation involving chromosome 9. Which of the following medications is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient is chronic myeloblastic leukemia (CML). Imatinib is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor that specifically targets the bcr-abl fusion protein responsible for CML.

  • In this elderly patient with systemic symptoms, splenomegaly, and hematologic abnormalities, hematologic malignancies including leukemias and lymphomas should be suspected.
  • These disorders are supported by the abnormal leukocytes seen on the peripheral blood smear.
  • The presence of the (9;22) chromosomal translocation (hinted at in the stem) indicates that this patient has CML. The (9;22) translocation - known as the Philadelphia chromosome - creates a novel fusion tyrosine kinase (bcr-abl).
  • The increased activity of this fusion protein results in high rates of cell division and inhibition of apoptosis.
  • Clinically, CML is often asymptomatic but can present with systemic symptoms (e.g., fatigue, weakness, night sweats, weight loss) and splenomegaly.
  • Imatinib is a targeted therapy that specifically blocks activity of the bcr-abl fusion protein.

Other Options:

Option B: Rituximab is an anti-CD20 monoclonal antibody that is used to treat hematologic malignancies, transplant rejection, and autoimmune disorders.

Option C: Trastuzumab is an anti-HER-2 monoclonal antibody used to treat HER-2-positive breast cancer.

Option D: Similar to imatinib, erlotinib is a receptor tyrosine kinase inhibitor. It specifically targets the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) and is used to treat multiple neoplasms including non-small cell lung cancer and pancreatic cancer.

Reference: Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas, and Aster, 10th Edition, Page Number 441.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male patient came to the ER with a history of RTA. You resuscitated the patient and got the CECT done. But on observation, the patient clinically deteriorated, so you decided to operate. There was major bleeding that was not controlled by just packing. What will be your next step in management? The following is shown in the CECT of the abdomen.
questions.solution:
The CECT shows a liver laceration with active bleeding.

The next best step in management is to perform a pringle manoeuvre.

A clamp is applied at the hepatoduodenal ligament at the epiploic foramen. If the bleeding stops, it is due to the portal vein, if not, the hepatic vein is implicated.


Reference - Sabiston, 21st edition, page 418.

questions.text:
A child is brought to the OP with a history of repeated injuries that seem to be non-accidental. A diagnosis of the battered baby syndrome is suspected. Which of the following clinical features are characteristic of the condition?
1. Subdural hemorrhage
2. Laceration over forehead
3. 'String of beads' appearance on chest X-ray
4. Bucket-handle fracture
5. Bruise over knee
questions.solution:
Statements 1, 3, and 4 are characteristic features of the battered baby syndrome.A battered baby syndrome refers to a constellation of clinical findings suggestive of repetitive physical abuse in a child via non-accidental violence by a parent or a guardian. There may be associated deprivation of nutrition, care, and affection. It is usually seen in children less than 3 years of age with a history of emotional or financial problems in the family.

Clinical features include:

  • Injuries of different ages and in different stages of healing.
  • Bruises may be seen on either side of the chest, behind the axillae, and down the anterior chest wall indicative of the hand impressions of the perpetrator. Shaking a child in such a position leads to infantile whiplash syndrome.
  • Repetitive and vigorous shaking of an infant gives rise to a triad of clinical findings - encephalopathy, retinal bleeds, and subdural hemorrhage.
  • Multiple deformities of the long bones and ribs. Some characteristic fractures include -

Knob fractures are a result of callus formation in healing ribs that have been damaged due to squeezing.

Chest X-ray shows a 'string of beads' appearance in the paravertebral gutter.

  • Bucket-handle fractures are typical corner fractures near the metaphyseal regions of the long bones in the arms and legs.

Forehead lacerations, knee bruises, and injuries on bony prominences are non-specific features that may be due to age-appropriate falls.

They are usually accidental and not characteristic of the condition.

Reference

Textbook of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology: Principles & Practice 5th edition

Page Nos. 331.

choices.text: Granules with tennis racket shape on electron microscopy
HLA-B27 gene variant on genetic testing
Neoplastic CD2+ and CD4+ cells on serology

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl has a painful rash on her head, headaches, increased thirst, and micturition. X-ray shows lytic skull lesions. What would further examination most likely reveal?
questions.solution:
This patient with diabetes insipidus, a scalp rash, and lytic skull lesions most likely have Hand-Schuller-Christian disease, which is a Langerhans cell histiocytosis disorder that presents with tennis racket-shaped granules on electron microscopy.

  • Langerhans cell histiocytoses are a class of disorders that demonstrate the proliferation of dendritic (Langerhans) cells from the monocyte lineage.
  • These cells normally present antigens to T-cells and characteristically have Birbeck granules, which are cytoplasmic rod-shaped granules with a terminal expansion and latticed matrix that can be seen on electron microscopy. These granules are often described as having a tennis racket appearance.
  • In particular, Hand-Schuller-Christian disease presents in adolescence and manifests with scalp rash, diabetes insipidus, lytic skull lesions, and exophthalmos though most patients do not have all four classic symptoms.

Other Options:

Option A: Anti-nuclear antibodies on serology are seen in a variety of autoimmune diseases including lupus; however, they would not be seen in Langerhans cell histiocytoses.

Option C: The HLA-B27 gene variant on genetic testing is associated with psoriasis as well as other inflammatory disorders; however, this gene variant is not associated with Langerhans cell histiocytoses.

Option D: Neoplastic CD2+ and CD4+ cells on serology would be seen in cutaneous T-cell lymphoma as well as T-cell leukemias; however, these cells are not found in Langerhans cell histiocytoses.

Reference: Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas, and Aster, 10th Edition, Page Number 441.

choices.text: Tumor necrosis factor-α and major basic protein

questions.text: Cytokines responsible for the migration of eosinophils in chronic sinusitis include
questions.solution:
Interleukin-4 and interleukin-5 are produced in the sinus mucosa by resident cells and infiltrating lymphocytes. These cytokines work in concert to induce the migration of eosinophils and prolong their survival.

The presence of eosinophils is characteristic of chronic sinus inflammation and contributes to the pathogenesis of the disease.

Reference: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition chapter no 34 Sinusitis and Polyposis page no 762.

questions.text: A 48-year-old male presents with shallow erosions and blisters with yellowish scales over the seborrheic area. Oral mucosa is spared. Direct immunofluorescence shows IgG deposition at the basement membrane. Serology shows anti-Dsg-1 positive. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis is pemphigus foliaceus (PF), an autoimmune disorder similar to pemphigus vulgaris.

Diagnosis of PF relies on a skin biopsy of a fresh lesion for histology to determine the site of blister formation and a confirmatory immunochemical study to document the presence of skin autoantibodies, either by direct immunofluorescence of perilesional skin or direct immunofluorescence (DIF) of ELISA.

The hallmark of PF is the finding of IgG autoantibodies against the cell surface of keratinocytes with DIF.

Oral mucosa is involved in cases of pemphigus vulgaris.


Reference - Rooks textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, chapter 35.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man presents after a rash that began in the last 2 days. The patient has numerous petechiae on his trunk, arms, and legs, as well as some areas of larger ecchymoses. He was treated for a viral illness a few weeks ago. His labs demonstrate the following:
Hb: 15 g/dl
Platelet count: 50,000/mm3
PT: 12 seconds
aPTT: 30 seconds
Which of the following is the likely mechanism of this disease?
questions.solution:
This patient with isolated thrombocytopenia in the setting of a recent viral illness likely has immune thrombocytopenic purpura, which results from antibodies against the platelet membrane.

  • Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) is a diagnosis of exclusion found in patients with thrombocytopenia in the setting of normal hemoglobin, normal white blood cell count, and normal coagulation studies.
  • Patients are often asymptomatic with evidence of petechiae or purpura.
  • It is caused by the production of IgG autoantibodies against glycolipids on the platelet membrane, leading to increased platelet destruction.
  • The platelet count is usually less than 100,000/mm3 and is associated with petechiae and bleeding. In severe cases, there can be internal hemorrhage.
  • While mild disease or no bleeding does not require therapy, patients at increased bleeding risk should be treated with intravenous immune globulin.
  • ITP often has a preceding history of viral illness.

Other Options:

Option B: Bone marrow failure can occur in a variety of settings, and can be inherited or acquired. This typically affects multiple cell lineages; this patient has isolated thrombocytopenia.

Option C: Deficiency of plasma metalloprotease (ADAMTS13) is seen in thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP). The loss of ADAMTS13 can be inherited or acquired and leads to widespread platelet thrombi in the microvasculature. This presents as microangiopathic hemolytic anemia with fever, thrombocytopenia, and renal and neurologic manifestations.

Option D: Toxin exposure can be seen in hemolytic uremic syndrome, wherein exposure to E. coli O157:H7 Shiga-toxin can also lead to the inactivation of ADAMTS13. This results in a thrombocytopenic, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia similar to TTP. HUS often has a preceding history of diarrhea and also has more renal involvement.

Reference: Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas, and Aster, 10th Edition, Page Number 441.

questions.text: Which of the following attitude will be seen in a patient with posterior dislocation of the hip?
questions.solution:
In posterior dislocation of the hip, the limb is flexed, internally rotated and adducted.

Dislocations of the hip are usually posterior, and occasionally anterior, or central through the acetabulum.


Central dislocation:

  • Trochanter is displaced medially.
  • One may be able to feel the head of the femur rectally.
  • There is no shortening of the leg.

Reference:Maheshwari ortho 5th edition, page no 130.

questions.text: True about Spasm of accommodation
questions.solution:
• Spasm of accommodation is caused by strong miotics such as ecothiophate and not generally due to pilocarpine. The treatment is with Atropine.
  • Overacting accommodation leads to focus on near objects thus inducing blurring of vision for far vision (Pseudomyopia).

Reference: Parson 22/e, P. 79.

questions.text: On noticing taurodontism in the post-mortem reports, you would suspect the body to be of an individual belonging to which of the following races?
questions.solution:
Common associations in Mongoloid teeth include-

  • Taurodontism or bull tooth - Wide and deep pulp cavity in molar teeth and fused and bent roots
  • Enamel pearls - Small nodules appearing on the tooth surface
  • Shovel-shaped upper central incisors
  • Congenital absence of the third upper molar

Other options -

Negroid races are found to have large teeth, multiple cusps (up to 8) on their molars, and 2 lingual cusps on the mandibular first premolars.

Caucasians have smaller lateral incisors than central incisors (seen especially in females), and long pointed canine roots. They are also found to have small nodules on the lingual surface of their maxillary molars known as 'Carabelli's cusp', which are most commonly associated with Caucasian races.

Reference:Knight's Forensic Pathology 4th edition, Page No. 559.

questions.text: If a patient is on a high protein diet, what will be the effect on the GFR?
questions.solution:
High protein intake increases GFR.

An increase in the plasma protein concentration is not the same as a high protein intake.

  • An increase in the plasma protein concentration decreases GFR due to a raised oncotic pressure.
  • A high protein intake raises the amino acid concentration in the blood, not the plasma protein concentration. It increases GFR.

Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 13th Edition Page no 345.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male presents with complaints of fatigue over the past 6 months. CBC reveals the following: Hb 9g/dL, Hct 27.0, and platelets 2,00,000. MCV is 76, ferritin of 15 ng/ml. Of the following, which is the next best step?
questions.solution:
The patient's presentation is consistent with iron deficiency anemia (IDA). In a patient of this age, colorectal cancer should be suspected, so a colonoscopy would be the next best step.

  • IDA is the most common cause of microcytic anemia.
  • Ferritin is the major physiologic storage form of iron, and low ferritin is very specific for IDA and is generally used to diagnose IDA.
  • However, elevated ferritin, an acute phase reactant, should be interpreted with caution in the context of underlying inflammatory processes or neoplasia and may not necessarily correlate with excess body iron stores.
  • Common causes of IDA include blood loss from the gastrointestinal tract and impaired absorption, such as in celiac disease.
  • A complete history is important to evaluate for potential causes of blood loss.
  • In older patients, gastrointestinal malignancy should always be considered and appropriately evaluated with upper endoscopy and colonoscopy if indicated.

Other Options:

Options A and C: CT and MRI are not indicated at this time in the workup of this patient's anemia, which is most likely due to occult GI blood loss. Colonoscopy is the appropriate screening for GI malignancy. Depending on the results of the initial scope, CT or PET may be indicated to look for metastatic disease.

Option C: Gel electrophoresis can be helpful in the diagnosis of thalassemia, which is another common cause of microcytic anemia but is less likely in this demographic.

Reference:

Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas and Aster, 10th Edition, Page Number 441

choices.text: Chronic loss of blood through the GI tract
Inflammation due to occult abdominal malignancy
Inhibition of ALA dehydratase and ferrochelatase

questions.text: Labs reveal microcytic anemia with high-normal levels of ferritin. Peripheral blood smear is shown. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism responsible for the anemia?
questions.solution:
This presentation is consistent with anemia due to lead poisoning in a child who likely moved to an old house with lead paint. Lead causes anemia by inhibition of the enzymes ALA dehydratase and ferrochelatase.

  • Lead poisoning anemia is a microcytic anemia that is caused by the inhibition of these two key enzymes in the porphyrin synthesis pathway.
  • This causes accumulation of iron in red blood cell precursors leading to the characteristic increased ferritin and basophilic stippling seen on laboratory tests.
  • Common symptoms reported in patients with lead poisoning include recurrent episodes of abdominal pain and anemia.
  • Encephalopathy may be present with high levels of exposure or chronic exposure in children.
  • Other findings include Burton's lead lines in bone radiographs.

Other Options:

Option A: Deletion of the beta hemoglobin gene is the cause of beta-thalassemia.

Option B: Chronic blood loss would lead to decreased ferritin levels.

Option C: Inflammation would cause anemia of chronic disease, which does not present with basophilic stippling.

Reference:

Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas, and Aster, 10th Edition, Page Number 441.

choices.text: Increases the speed of cardiac conduction
May be used in 0.25% solution for intravenous regional anesthesia
The hyperbaric solution for spinal anesthesia contains 60 mg/ml of dextrose

questions.text: Pick the true statement in regards to Bupivacaine.
questions.solution:
Bupivacaine is an amide local anaesthetic which is contraindicated for intravenous regional anesthesia.

The hyperbaric solution contains 80 mg/ml of glucose. 0.5% solution has 5 mg/ml.

It decreases the speed of cardiac conduction.

Reference - Pinnock CA, Lin ES, Smith T. Fundamentals of Anaesthesia, 2nd Edn. Greenwich Medical Media Ltd, 2003, Section 3: Chapter 9

choices.text: Timely administration of intravenous amphotericin B.
Surgical debridement of involved nasal and sinus tissue.
Magnetic resonance imaging of sinuses to evaluate the extent of the disease.

questions.text: The most critical factor in the successful treatment for fulminant invasive fungal sinusitis in a patient in diabetic ketoacidosis is
questions.solution:
Although all of the choices are valid elements of the treatment for fulminant invasive fungal sinusitis, the most critical issue is control of the underlying disease process. The disease process is uniformly fatal if the immunocompromised state cannot be reversed, even with maximal medical and surgical therapy.

Reference: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition chapter no 34 Sinusitis and Polyposis page no 762.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male patient presented with a road traffic accident. During the initial 24 hours of injury, which of the following is not expected?
questions.solution:
The metabolic response to injury in humans can be divided into 'ebb' and 'flow' phases.

The ebb phase begins at the time of injury and lasts for approximately 24-48 hours. It may be attenuated by proper resuscitation, but not completely abolished.

The ebb phase is characterised by -

  • Hypovolemia
  • Decreased basal metabolic rate
  • Reduced cardiac output
  • Hypothermia
  • Lactic acidosis

The predominant hormones regulating the ebb phase are catecholamines, cortisol and aldosterone (following activation of the renin-angiotensin system).

The main physiological role of the ebb phase is to conserve both circulating volume and energy stores for recovery and repair.

Following resuscitation, the ebb phase evolves into a hypermetabolic flow phase, which corresponds to SIRS.

This phase involves the mobilization of body energy stores for recovery and repair, and the subsequent replacement of lost or damaged tissue.

It is characterized by -

  • Tissue edema (from vasodilatation and increased capillary leakage)
  • Increased basal metabolic rate (hypermetabolism)
  • Increased cardiac output
  • Raised body temperature
  • Leukocytosis
  • Increased oxygen consumption
  • Increased gluconeogenesis

Reference - Bailey 27th ed, pg 5

questions.text: The windkessel effect is seen in-
questions.solution:
The windkessel effect is seen in large elastic vessels.

The aorta, the pulmonary artery, and their major branches have a large amount of elastin in their walls. Hence, they have a high elastic recoil effect. This property of elastic recoil is called windkessel effect.

Reference - Berne and Levy Physiology 7th edition pg no 351.

questions.text: What is the malignant potential of a complete mole?
questions.solution:
The rate of development of gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN) from a complete mole is 15-20%.

Reference: William's obstetrics 26th edition, Page no 236.

questions.text: Using an electron microscope we would be able to resolve points that are how close apart?
questions.solution:
Using an electron microscope the resident would be able to resolve points that are 0. 1 nm apart, which is the resolving power of an electron microscope.

The wavelength of electrons used is approximately 0.005 nm.

Ernst Ruska designed the first electron microscope, enabling us to view viruses.

  • In an electron microscope, a beam of electrons is used instead of a beam of light used in the optical microscope.
  • The electron beam is focused by circular electromagnets (analogous to the Lenses in the light microscope).
  • The object which is present in the path of the beam scatters the electrons and produces an image that is focused on a fluorescent viewing screen.

Reference:

Ananthanarayan and Panikers Textbook of Microbiology Tenth edition, pg no 4,12.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with gross hematuria, proteinuria, and acute, colicky flank pain. She reports taking high doses of acetaminophen and aspirin. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Acute onset of gross hematuria, colicky flank pain, and proteinuria are characteristics of renal papillary necrosis.

Papillary necrosis is caused by the sloughing of necrosed renal papillae into the urinary space. It is associated with several diseases that prompt ischemia of the renal papillae, including analgesic nephropathy, sickle cell disease or trait, diabetes mellitus, and acute pyelonephritis.

Overuse of non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) causes analgesic nephropathy by decreasing prostaglandin synthesis, leading to constriction of the glomerular afferent arteriole.

Other Options:

Option A: Diffuse cortical necrosis is marked by acute infarction of both kidneys. It is associated with obstetric catastrophes and septic shock.

Option B: Chronic pyelonephritis presents with white cell casts in the urine and is not associated with hematuria.

Option C: Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) presents with hypertension, flank pain, hematuria, urinary infection, and signs of renal failure.

Reference:

Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas, and Aster, 10th Edition, Page Number 549.

choices.text: The delusion used in defense, if true, would justify the crime

questions.text: To plead not guilty by reason of insanity, which of the following justification can be given for the crime?
questions.solution:
• According to criminal law, committing an act that is socially harmful is not the sole criterion of whether a crime has been committed. Instead, the objectionable act must have two components: voluntary conduct (actus reus) and evil intent (mens rea).
  • An evil intent cannot exist when an offender's mental status is so deficient, so abnormal, or so diseased to have deprived the offender of the capacity for rational intent.
  • The so-called M'Naghten rule that determines criminal responsibility, holds that persons are not guilty by reason of insanity if they labored under a mental disease such that they were unaware of the nature, the quality, and the consequences of their acts or if they were incapable of realizing that their acts were wrong.
  • Moreover, to absolve persons from punishment, a delusion used as evidence must be one that, if true, would be an adequate defense. If the delusional idea does not justify the crime, such persons are presumably held responsible, guilty, and punishable.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Chapter 36.1 Forensic Psychiatry, Page number 1389.

questions.text: A 61-year-old man has progressive shortness of breath on exertion. Pulmonary examination shows fine bibasilar end-inspiratory crackles. PFT shows a FEV1:FVC ratio of 97% and a total lung capacity of 70%. CXR shows small bilateral reticular opacities, predominantly in the lower lobes. Lung biopsy is shown. The patient most likely works in which of the following fields?
questions.solution:
The patient presents with chronic, progressive dyspnea and shows a restrictive pattern of lung disease on pulmonary function tests (normal to increased FEV1:FVC ratio, decreased TLC). The photomicrograph of the lung biopsy specimen shows several dumbbell-shaped ferruginous bodies, which are collections of iron and protein-coating asbestos fibers.

Shipbuilders might be exposed to asbestos, as it is a highly resilient material that is an optimal insulator and was widely used before its dangers were known. Other patients at high risk for occupational exposure to asbestos include construction workers (plumbing, roofing, insulation) and firefighters (heat-resistant clothing). The incidence of asbestosis is dependent on cumulative exposure. While asbestosis usually affects the lower lobes, other pneumoconioses (e.g., due to silica, coal, beryllium) tend to affect the upper lobes of the lungs. The most commonly associated malignancies of asbestosis are bronchogenic carcinoma, followed by mesothelioma.

Other Options:

Option B: Workers in aerospace manufacturing are often exposed to beryllium alloys, which can cause berylliosis after high-grade exposure.

Option C: Cattle farmers are chronically exposed to organic dust (e.g., from molds, animal proteins) and are at risk for chronic hypersensitivity pneumonia.

Option D: Workers exposed to silica dust (e.g., in sandblasting, mining, and casting metals) are at risk for silicosis, which usually presents with a mixed obstructive-restrictive pattern on pulmonary function tests.

Reference:

Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas, and Aster, 10th Edition, Page Number 49.

questions.text: A 65 years old male was brought to casualty with a history of fall. The patient is in severe pain, there is tenderness on the greater trochanter and also the patient is not able to walk. The lateral border of the foot touches the bed. What is the most common complication in the given clinical scenario?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario depicts the inter-trochanteric femur fracture.

Intertrochanteric femur fracture presents with the following clinical features:-

  • Painful movements of the hip joint
  • Shortening and external rotation of the affected limb
  • Extra-capsular (inter-trochanteric) fracture is more common than intra-capsular.
  • Most common complication of extra-capsular fracture of the neck of the femur is malunion.
  • In inter-trochanteric fractures, there is usually gross deformity and pronounced lateral rotation.
