  • Inter-trochanteric fractures almost always unite, but because of possible failure in keeping the fragments aligned, these are often malunited. Malunion gives rise to coxa vara (decreased femoral neck-shaft angle), shortening, and the leg in external rotation.

Reference: Maheshwari ortho 5th edition, page no 139.

questions.text: The greatest total cross-sectional area in the circulatory system is of
questions.solution:
• The greatest total cross-sectional area in the circulatory system is of the capillaries.
  • The total cross-sectional area is minimum for the aorta.

Reference - Ganong's Review Of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Page no: 559.

questions.text: The below image is taken from a 70-year-old woman who complained of left epiphora and ocular irritation. She had left lower lid basal cell carcinoma excision six months earlier. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient most likely has cicatricial ectropion of the left lower lid.

Defects in the lower lid that are closed horizontally (with the lines of langer) can occasionally shorten the anterior lamellae and produce postoperative cicatricial ectropion.

Cicatricial ectropion is caused by scarring or contracture of the skin and the underlying tissues which pulls the eyelid away from the globe.

Floppy eyelid syndrome affects obese middle-aged or older men. The upper eyelid is typically involved.

Reference: Kanski 7/e, p.46 48

questions.text: What is the average age of puberty in girls?
questions.solution:
Average age of puberty in girls is about 10.5 years.

Reference: Dutta's Textbook of Gynecology 8th edition, Chapter- puberty.

questions.text: Which of the following radiologic studies is the most valuable for evaluating deep neck infections?
questions.solution:
Contrast-enhanced CT is excellent for evaluation of all of the fascial spaces and may demonstrate findings of infections such as soft tissue edema, obliteration of fat planes, deviation of structures, and airway compromise.

It can differentiate between abscess and cellulitis.

It will demonstrate the size and location of an abscess and its position relative to the carotid artery and internal jugular vein.

Reference: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition chapter no 44 Diseases of the Oral Cavity, Oropharynx, and Nasopharynx page no 1038.

questions.text: A male patient presents to the OPD with complaints of fever with chills, headache, abdominal pain, and diarrhea. He gives a history of consuming raw refrigerated vegetables 24 hours back. What is the type of motility shown by the most likely etiologic organism when it is cultured at 25°C?
questions.solution:
Swarming motility is seen with Bacillus cereus. It has two distinct forms.

Darting motility is seen with Vibrio cholerae. It is actively motile with a polar flagellum. It results

in watery diarrhea with characteristic rice-watery stools. Shellfish (oysters), especially raw and undercooked food, are the common source for Vibrio species, especially V. parahaemolyticus.

Falling leaf motility is seen with Giardia lamblia. It is the common pathogenic protozoan found in the duodenum of humans. Infection is acquired by the consumption of water or food contaminated with cysts and may also be transmitted by the fecal-oral route. The symptoms include acute or chronic diarrhea, weight loss, malaise, abdominal cramps, distension, and weakness.

Listeria monocytogenes is a short, Gram-positive bacteria with tumbling motility.

Reference

Jawetz, Melnick & adelberg 28 edition pg no 200,201,186,727,261, 263.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes for surgery on pancreatic insulinoma. While taking a surgical history, she tells you she previously had a pituitary tumor resected. For which additional neoplasms might you consider testing her?
questions.solution:
Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia (MEN) Type I (also known as Wermer syndrome) is due to defects in the MENIN gene leading to -

  • Pituitary adenoma
  • Pancreatic cancers
  • Parathyroid tumors (the three Ps).

As she has pituitary adenoma, and a current pancreatic insulinoma, she should be examined for parathyroid adenoma.

MEN type I may also be distinguished by the presence of other neuroendocrine tumors, including bronchial cancers causing carcinoid syndrome, adrenal tumors leading to Cushing syndrome, or digestive tumors such as gastrinomas, insulinomas, or somatostatinomas.

The mutation in MENIN is autosomal dominant, so relatives should additionally be screened.

Other Options:

Options A & B: Medullary thyroid carcinoma and pheochromocytoma are features of both MEN Type IIa (also known as Sipple syndrome) and Type IIb.

Option D: Mucosal neuromas and marfanoid habitus are additional features of MEN type IIb.

Reference:

Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas, and Aster, 10th Edition, Page Number 749.

questions.text: Which position of the fetus is more frequently associated with low back pain in the mother?
questions.solution:
As the occiput lies posteriorly, it causes pressure on the back leading to back pain.

Reference: William' obstetrics 26th edition, Page no 314.

questions.text:
Which of the following is true about perthes' disease?
1. Avascular necrosis of femoral head
2. Onset before 10 years of age
3. Osteotomy is used for treatment
4. Limb shortening
questions.solution:
Perthes' disease (Coxa plana, Pseudo Coxalgia) is an osteochondritis of the femoral head. The femoral head becomes partly or wholly avascular and deformed.

Etiology is not definitely known. It is supposed to be due to recurrent episodes of ischemia of the femoral head in the susceptible age group, probably precipitated by episodes of synovitis.

Pathology:

The disease progresses in three ill-defined stages:

  • Stage of synovitis
  • Stage of trabecular necrosis
  • Stage of healing

Clinical features:

Commonly seen in the age group of 5 to 10 years.

The child presents with pain in the hip which often radiates to the knee or may also present with limb or hip stiffness. On examination, the findings are minimal. Sometimes the only finding is the limitation of abduction and internal rotation and shortening.

X-Ray shows collapse and sclerosis of the epiphysis of the femoral head. Hip joint space is increased. A bone scan may show a decreased uptake by the head of the femur.

Treatment:

The primary aim is to prevent the head from ill shaping while the bone is in the softening phase.

The head is required to be kept inside the acetabulum while the revascularization takes place (i.e. containment).

This may be achieved by corrective methods (plaster, splint, etc.) or by operation (containment osteotomy).

Reference: Maheshwari ortho 5th edition, page no 318.

choices.text: Effect of one non-diffusible ion on the distribution of other non-diffusible ions
Effect of one permeant ion on the distribution of other permeant ions
Effect of a permeant ion on the distribution of non-diffusible ions
Effect of a non-diffusible ion on the distribution of permeant ions

questions.text: Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium explains the
questions.solution:
Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium explains the effect of a non-diffusible ion on the distribution of permeant ions.

This says that in the presence of a non-diffusible ion, the diffusible ions distribute themselves so that at equilibrium their concentration ratios are equal.

Reference - Ganong's Review Of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition Page no.8.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a lump in her neck. Her past medical history is significant for non-Hodgkin lymphoma which was treated with radiation 21 years ago. A physical examination demonstrates an irregularly-shaped, pea-sized nodule that does not move when the patient swallows. A biopsy is performed. In addition to these results, what is another distinguishing factor that differentiates this condition from other thyroid cancers?
questions.solution:
This patient has papillary thyroid cancer (e.g., adherent thyroid nodule with Orphan Annie eyes on biopsy and a history of radiation). In addition to Orphan Annie eyes, papillary thyroid cancer is also characterized by psammoma bodies, which are microscopic dystrophic calcific collections.

  • Papillary thyroid carcinoma is the most common form of thyroid cancer and has an excellent prognosis.
  • Risk factors include radiation exposure, positive family history, and RET and BRAF mutations.
  • Patients often present with a thyroid nodule that is discovered incidentally.
  • Characteristics that suggest malignancy include rapid nodular growth, fixation of the nodule, new-onset hoarseness, vocal cord paralysis, and ipsilateral cervical lymphadenopathy.
  • Histologically, papillary cancers are typically unencapsulated, partially cystic, with characteristic psammoma bodies and Orphan Annie eyes (empty-appearing nuclei with central clearing).

Other Options:

Option A: Association with Hashimoto thyroiditis is seen in the lymphoma of the thyroid, which often presents as a rapidly enlarging neck mass that results in respiratory difficulty. Histopathology would demonstrate the properties of non-Hodgkin B-cell lymphomas.

Option B: Capsular invasion can be seen with follicular carcinoma, which on histology appears as follicular cells that invade the thyroid capsule. Papillary thyroid carcinoma is usually not encapsulated.

Option C: Poor prognosis is not a characteristic of papillary thyroid carcinoma as the disease usually has an excellent prognosis.

Reference:

Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas, and Aster, 10th Edition, Page Number 749.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male is due to get married after a month. He thinks he will embarrass himself around other people in the marriage ceremony by how he dresses, eats, or speaks. Thinking about the ceremony makes him anxious. He has recently started experiencing panic attacks too. Although there have been no problems in his relationship with his partner. This is not new for him as he has always been anxious around people and even while giving presentations. The most favourable diagnosis for him would be
questions.solution:
Social anxiety disorder refers to marked fear or anxiety about one or more social situations in which the individual is exposed to possible scrutiny by others.

Examples include:

  • Social interactions (e.g., having a conversation, meeting unfamiliar people)
  • Being observed (e.g., eating or drinking)
  • Performing in front of others (e.g., giving a speech)

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, Eleventh edition, Chapter 9.5, Social Anxiety disorder (Social Phobia), Page 406.

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice for carcinoma cervix stage IIB?
questions.solution: Reference: William's Gynecology, 3rd edition, page 668.

questions.text: The most common muscle involved in thyroid ophthalmopathy is
questions.solution:
Elevation defect is caused earliest by fibrotic contracture of the inferior rectus.

Reference: Kanski 7/e, p. 78.

questions.text: A 21-year-old patient presents to you with persistent headaches and blurring of vision. On examination, there is papilledema and MRI revealed an infratentorial mass. He gives a family history of cancer of the kidney in his father. The patient undergoes surgical resection of the mass. A photomicrograph of the resected specimen is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with an infratentorial brain tumor and abnormal capillary growth in the resected specimen. In combination with a family history of renal cell carcinoma, this raises suspicion for von Hippel-Lindau disease (VHL).

  • Hemangioblastomas are rare, highly vascularized, infratentorial brain tumors, that may occur sporadically or as a manifestation of VHL disease.
  • As in this case, patients often present with features of increased intracranial pressure (e.g., headache, vomiting, blurred vision, papilledema).
  • Hemangioblastomas are further associated with polycythemia, caused by paraneoplastic erythropoietin production.
  • Histology shows densely packed, thin-walled capillary vessels surrounded by large stromal cells with intracytoplasmic lipid inclusions.
  • VHL-associated tumors most commonly occur in early adulthood and include hemangioblastomas of the spine, cerebellum, and retina (commonly bilateral and peripherally located), renal cell carcinomas, pheochromocytomas, and pancreatic cysts.

Reference: Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas and Aster, 10th Edition, Page Number 849.

choices.text: Regular follow-up with ALT and HBV DNA Quantitative

questions.text: A 43year male presented with chronic hepatitis B infection to your OPD for further advice regarding management. On investigation, he has ALT: 85IU/L, AST: 92 IU/L, Normal PT, and A/G ratio with normal liver on USG abdomen. The patient is HBeAg negative and has HBV DNA levels of 23,514IU/mL. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The decision to initiate antiviral therapy is primarily based on the presence or absence of cirrhosis, and HBeAg status, ALT and HBV DNA levels.

So performing a liver biopsy on this patient is needed at this point (Gold standard for diagnosis of cirrhosis).

The indications for starting antivirals in patients with chronic hepatitis B include -

  • Patients without cirrhosis -
  • HBeAg positive with HBV DNA >20000 IU/ml and ALT levels >2 times the upper limit of normal.
  • HBeAg negative with HBV DNA >2000 IU/ml and ALT levels >2 times the upper limit of normal.
  • Patients with compensated cirrhosis and an HBV DNA >2000 IU/ml.
  • Patients developing acute liver failure or decompensated cirrhosis.

Reference: Harrisons' Principles of Internal medicine, 20th Ed, Pg No: 2383.

choices.text: The child most likely has bronchiolitis and is at risk of respiratory failure.
The child most likely has bronchiolitis, and his symptoms should resolve in the emergency department with additional albuterol treatments.
The child should undergo upper endoscopy, as you suspect a tracheoesophageal fistula.
The child most likely has gastroesophageal reflux and has aspirated.

questions.text: A well-developed 4-month-old boy presents to the ED on a cold winter night with the complaint of worsening respiratory distress and decreased oral intake. His parents report that he was well until yesterday when he developed upper respiratory symptoms and a low-grade fever. Upon examination of the child, you note pallor and perioral cyanosis, a respiratory rate of 65 breaths/min, and tight wheezes throughout the chest. An arterial blood gas shows a pH of 7.15, a pCO2 of 65 mm Hg, and a serum bicarbonate of 20 mmol/L. Which of the following is the most likely explanation regarding the child's condition?
questions.solution:
The differential diagnosis for a wheezing baby is extensive. However, the sudden onset of respiratory symptoms in a previously healthy infant, particularly in association with fever, is most consistent with the diagnosis of bronchiolitis. Initial treatment for this baby includes oxygen and a trial of nebulized albuterol or epinephrine.

A blood gas measurement should be obtained immediately for any patient who presents with severe respiratory distress. This child's blood gas indices show marked respiratory acidosis. He will likely require mechanical ventilation and monitoring in an intensive care setting until his symptoms improve. Infants with wheezing caused by bronchiolitis do not always respond to β-agonists.

Chest radiographs in infants with bronchiolitis typically show hyperinflated lungs with areas of atelectasis.

Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) and influenza A are common causes of bronchiolitis in infants in the wintertime, but several other viral causes are also possible.

A careful history should be obtained to rule out less common causes of wheezing in an infant, such as recurrent aspiration or a congenital anomaly.

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20th ed., pg. 2045.

questions.text: 45year old male presented with chronic diarrhea and pedal edema. Intestinal biopsy shows the following picture. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Pedal edema, chronic diarrhea with characteristic biopsy findings are highly suggestive of intestinal lymphangiectasia.

Intestinal lymphangiectasia is a medical condition in which the lymphatic vessels in the intestines are dilated or enlarged. This results in the accumulation of lymph fluid in the intestinal tissue, leading to a variety of symptoms such as abdominal swelling, diarrhea, malabsorption, and malnutrition. The cause of lymphangiectasia is not always clear, but it can be associated with certain underlying medical conditions, such as congenital heart disease, Crohn's disease, or damage to the lymphatic system.

Diagnosis of intestinal lymphangiectasia may involve a combination of tests, including physical examination, imaging studies, and biopsy of the affected tissue. Treatment depends on the underlying cause and severity of the condition but may include medications to manage symptoms, changes in diet, and in severe cases, surgery to remove the affected tissue.

Biopsy findings include - Dilated lymphatics in the submucosa and sometimes in the lamina propria with clubbed villi.

Reference: Harrison's 20e, 2252.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman, is currently 10 weeks pregnant. She has another child, who is 7 months old currently. After the delivery of her first child, she started experiencing symptoms of feeling low and tearful, reduced sleep, feeling tired and exhausted. Even now, she feels quite skeptical about her current pregnancy and feels she is a 'bad mother'. What percentage of new mothers are believed to develop such symptoms?
questions.solution:
• Postpartum depression is relatively common, occurring in about 10% to 15% of new mothers.
  • Symptoms are indistinguishable from those characteristics of nonpsychotic major depression.
  • Symptoms usually develop insidiously over the 6 months following delivery.
  • Ambivalence toward the child and doubts about the mother's own parenting abilities are common, but the rate of suicide is low.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, Eleventh Edition, Chapter 27 Psychiatry, and Reproductive Medicine, page no 839.

questions.text: At the time of weaning a patient from the ventilator, which of the following situation is considered as a failure of spontaneous breathing trial?
questions.solution:
The spontaneous breathing trial is declared a failure and stopped if any of the following occur:

  • Respiratory rate >35/min for >5 minutes
  • O2 saturation <90%
  • Heart rate >140/min or a 20% increase or decrease from baseline
  • Systolic blood pressure <90 mmHg or >180 mmHg
  • Increased anxiety or diaphoresis

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition, chapter 293.

choices.text: Determining what the girl was playing with and ordering a chest radiograph
Referring the child to a pulmonologist
Prescribing antibiotics for a likely pneumonia
Administering an injection of intramuscular prednisone and sending her home

questions.text: A previously healthy 2-year-old girl presents with the complaint of acute onset wheezing. Her mother denies previous wheezing episodes and denies a family history of asthma or atopy. The mother says that she left the child playing in her older brother's room. Approximately 20 minutes later she heard the child coughing and wheezing. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
Young children, generally between 4 months and 3 years of age, normally put objects in their mouths, and they are prone to developing foreign-body aspirations.

A pulmonologist ultimately may be needed to retrieve the object, but this would not be the first step. Determining what the girl was playing with and ordering a chest radiograph would be the initial approach.

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20th ed., pg. 2039.

questions.text: All of the following changes are seen in dysplasia of squamocolumnar junction except-
questions.solution:
In question, they have asked about dysplasia.

Breaking of the basement membrane becomes the feature of invasive carcinoma.

Reference - William's Gynecology, 3rd edition, page 632.

questions.text: An injury to the shown area can lead to fracture of which bone?
questions.solution:
Anatomical snuff box: The given picture shows an anatomical snuff box which Is a depression formed at the posterolateral side of the wrist and metacarpal by the extensor tendons passing into the thumb. The base of the triangle is at the wrist and the apex is directed into the thumb. It is most apparent when the thumb is extended.

Boundaries:

Lateral: Abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis tendons.

Medial: Extensor pollicis longus tendon

Floor: Scaphoid and trapezium the distal ends of the tendons of the extensor carpi radialis longus and extensor carpi radialis brevis

Scaphoid Fracture:

The commonest carpal injury is a fracture across the waist of the scaphoid bone It is uncommon to see other injuries. In approximately 10% of individuals, the scaphoid bone has a sole blood supply from the radial artery, which enters through the distal portion of the bone to supply the proximal portion. When the fracture occurs across the waist of the scaphoid, the proximal portion, therefore, undergoes avascular necrosis.

Reference: Maheshwari ortho 5th edition page no 115.

questions.text: Pupillomotor fibres of third cranial nerve travel along with
questions.solution:
Pupillomotor fibres of the third cranial nerve travel along with the nerve to the inferior oblique muscle.



Reference: Kanski 7/e, p. 812.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of patiromer?
questions.solution:
Patiromer is a potassium-binding resin used in the treatment of hyperkalemia. It promotes potassium loss through the GI tract and helps reduce the incidence of hyperkalemia.

Other examples of potassium-binding resins include calcium resonium and sodium polystyrene.

Kaliuretic diuretics treat hyperkalemia by promoting urinary potassium excretion.

Reference - Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 21st edition, page 2313.

questions.text: Which of the following postmortem changes is not a feature of normal decomposition?
questions.solution:
Saponification or adipocere is a postmortem change that is not a feature of normal decomposition.

  • It is characterized by the formation of a waxy, greasy, and whitish substance with a sweet, rancid odor.
  • It resembles the consistency of soap.
  • The pattern of distribution includes areasof fatty tissues in the dead body.
  • Adipocere consists primarily of fatty acids that are produced due to postmortem hydrolysis and the hydrogenation of body fats. It is a water-dependent process that involves the conversion of unsaturated liquid fats to saturated solid fats.

Medicolegal importance is as follows;

  • It is the surestsign of death
  • It gives a rough estimate of the time since death
  • The cause of death can be identified. In the face, the features are well preserved and therefore used in identification.

Other options:

Option A: Right iliac fossa discoloration is the first external sign of decomposition, and is due to the action of C.welchii in the ileocecal portion of the gastrointestinal tract. Bacterially produced hydrogen sulfide combines with hemoglobin to give rise to sulfhemoglobin which causes discoloration.

Option B: Subsequently, bacterial dissemination takes place through the blood vessels causing similar discoloration of the superficial blood vessels. A linear branching pattern is formed known as marbling.

Option C: The process of decomposition destroys the anatomic integrity of skin which leads to localized peeling known as skin slippage and loosening of the skin of hands and feet known as degloving.

Reference:The Essentials of Forensic Medicine And Toxicology 33rd edition Page no 165.

questions.text: In which of the following disease D-Xylose test will be abnormal?
questions.solution:
URINARY d-XYLOSE TEST

  • The urinary d-xylose test for carbohydrate absorption provides an assessment of proximal small-intestinal mucosal function.
  • d-Xylose, a pentose, is absorbed almost exclusively in the proximal small intestine.
  • The d-xylose test is usually performed by administering 25 g of d-xylose and collecting urine for 5 h.
  • An abnormal test (excretion of <4.5 g) primarily reflects duodenal/jejunal mucosal disease.
  • The d-xylose test can also be abnormal in patients with blind loop syndrome (as a consequence primarily of an abnormal intestinal mucosa) and, as a false-positive study, in patients with large collections of fluid in a third space (i.e., ascites, pleural fluid).


Reference - Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition, chapter 318.

questions.text: A 30-year-old marathon runner presents with persistent pain over the dorsum of the foot on weight bearing. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
March/Stress fracture:-

  • March fractures are metatarsal fractures, most commonly second and third metatarsal fractures.
  • They are caused by an overuse injury. The repetitive impact on the metatarsals with weight-bearing exercises causes micro fractures, which consolidate to stress fractures.
  • The most common location of metatarsal stress fractures is the second metatarsal neck. Distal second metatarsal stress fractures are the most common due to the high bending and shear forces. Further risk factors include a long 2nd metatarsal, hypermobile first ray, and women.
  • Radiographs may be negative or show callus formation.
  • High-risk populations include runners, military recruits, ballet dancers, basketball players, or those with a recent increase in activity or training.
  • Advanced imaging of a bone scan or MRI can be obtained to confirm the diagnosis in cases of negative radiographs.
  • Initial treatment usually involves activity modification with a gradual return to sport over 6-8 weeks when asymptomatic.
  • Use of a walking boot, cast, or limiting weight-bearing can be used in patients whose symptoms don't resolve with activity modification or cannot comply with the recommendations.


Morton's neuroma affects the third (most common) or second distal metatarsal interspace. The pain is typically reproduced by laterally compressing the forefoot while also compressing the affected interspace - this produces the pathognomic Mulder'sclick as the 'neuroma' displaces between the metatarsal heads.

In plantar fasciitis, there is tenderness over the medial aspect of the calcaneal tuberosity, at the site of attachment of the plantar fascia. It is worst in the morning and improves with activity.

Reference: Maheshwari ortho 5th edition page no 166.

questions.text: Two weeks after a viral syndrome, a 2-year-old develops bruising and generalized petechiae that are more prominent over the legs. He has neither hepatosplenomegaly nor lymph node enlargement. Laboratory testing reveals normal hemoglobin, hematocrit, and white blood cell count and differential. The platelet count is 15,000/mm3. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Immune (or idiopathic) thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) is common in children. In most cases, a preceding viral infection can be documented. The platelet count frequently is less than 20,000/mm3, but other laboratory test results are normal, including the bone marrow aspiration (which may show an increase in megakaryocytes).
  • Treatment consists of observation or possibly intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG), intravenous anti-D (in Rh-positive patients), immunosuppressants, or steroids.
  • The history must be reviewed for other possible causes of thrombocytopenia, including recent MMR vaccination, drug ingestion, and human immunodeficiency virus.

Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura is a rare pentad of fever, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, abnormal renal function, and central nervous system changes

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20th ed., pg. 2402.

choices.text: Spider angiomata and palmar erythema occur in both acute and chronic liver disease
Spider angiomata typically fill from the center outwards
Spider angiomata and palmar erythema are not typically seen in normal individual

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about the liver disease except :
questions.solution:
• Spider angiomata and palmar erythema occur in both acute and chronic liver disease.
  • These manifestations may be especially prominent in persons with cirrhosis but can develop in normal individuals and are frequently found during pregnancy.
  • Spider angiomata are superficial, tortuous arterioles, and-unlike simple telangiectases-typically fill from the center outward.
  • Spider angiomata occur only on the arms, face, and upper torso.
  • They can be pulsatile and may be difficult to detect in dark-skinned individuals.

Reference - Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition, chapter 330.

questions.text: Image is suggestive of which condition?
questions.solution:
The image shows a uterine inversion.

Puerperal inversion of the uterus is one of the classic hemorrhagic disasters encountered in obstetrics. Unless promptly recognized and managed accordingly, the associated bleeding is massive.

Risk factors include -

  • Fundal implantation of placenta
  • Uterine atony
  • Cord traction applied before placental separation
  • Abnormally adherent placenta

Reference: William's obstetrics 26th edition, Page no 738.

questions.text: All of the following causes iron deficiency anemia because of increased demand for iron except
questions.solution:
Acute or chronic inflammation causes iron deficiency anemia due to decreased iron intake or absorption.

Increased Demand for Iron -

  • Rapid growth in infancy or adolescence
  • Pregnancy
  • Erythropoietin therapy

Reference - Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition, chapter 93.

questions.text: 3 days after beginning oral amoxicillin therapy for otitis media, a 4-year-old boy has continued fever, ear pain, and swelling with redness behind his ear. His ear lobe is pushed superiorly and laterally. He seems to be doing well otherwise. Which of the following is the most appropriate course of action?
questions.solution:
The child has mastoiditis, a clinical diagnosis that can require computed tomography scan confirmation.

Treatment includes myringotomy, fluid culture, and parenteral antibiotics.

Surgical drainage of the mastoid air cells may be needed if the improvement is not seen in 24 to 48 hours.

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20th ed., pg. 3097.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman was diagnosed with cholelithiasis, for which she was posted for laparoscopic cholecystectomy. One of the concerns about this surgery is to prevent intra-operative injury to the artery supplying the gall bladder, for which a particular triangle is identified as shown below. Which of the following is not a boundary of this triangle?
questions.solution:
The triangle shown above is the CALOT'S TRIANGLE. It is identified during gall bladder surgeries to avoid injury to the cystic artery.

Its boundaries are-

  • Above- Cystic artery
  • Below and to the right- Cystic duct
  • Below and to the left- Common hepatic duct
  • Contents- Cystic node of lund

Inferior surface of liver is a boundary of hepatocystic triangle, which forms its upper boundary.

Content includes cystic artery.

Reference: BD Chaurasia's Human Anatomy, regional and applied, 8th edition, volume 2, page 336.

questions.text: An 18-year-old gentleman presented with a history of chest pain, tachypnea, fever, cough, and arterial oxygen desaturation. Due to his pre-existing disease, he was diagnosed to have acute chest syndrome. Which of the following is the most likely pre-existing disease-causing acute chest syndrome?
questions.solution:
• Acute chest syndrome is a pneumonia-like illness is the second most frequent acute sickle cell-related event.
  • It occurs in >50% of patients, often more than once.
  • It can be mild, especially in children, in whom it can result from a viral infection, or devastating, where multiple lobes of the lung are affected with severe hypoxia, multiorgan failure, and death.
  • Chest pain, cough, fever, hypoxia, and a pulmonary infiltrate on chest x-ray are the major diagnostic criteria.
  • The etiology includes in situ thrombosis, emboli, any type of infection, and postoperative hypoventilation.


Reference - Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 21st edition, page 760.

choices.text: Concentrated focal impact on the skull
Forcible contact with a broad resisting surface
Fall from a height onto feet or buttocks

questions.text: Which of the following mechanisms can cause the skull fracture shown below?
questions.solution:
The image shown is representative of a linear fracture, else known as a fissured fracture, formed on the outer and posterior surface of the skull.

  • They are most commonly caused by forcible contact of the skull with a broad resisting surface like the ground or a wall.
  • Not associated with displacement of bone fragments.
  • May either involve the complete thickness of bone or either one of the tables.
  • The fracture line follows an irregular course that is parallel to the axis of compression and is almost indiscernible on X-ray.

Diastasis is the term used to describe the weakening of a skull suture when the fracture line passes through it.

Other options:

Option A - Concentrated focal impact on the skull causes a depressed/ signature fracture. Violent blows from blunt objects such as a hammer, damage the bone in the same dimensions as associated with the object thereby producing an impression (signature) of the offending object.

Option B - Oblique bullet wounds cause a furrow due to the removal of a part of the thickness of the skull bone. This gives rise to a gutter fracture. It is frequently associated with a comminuted depressed fracture of the inner table of the skull.

Option D - Falling from a height onto feet or buttocks is the mechanism responsible for a ring fracture. This fracture encircles the foramen magnum and passes through the middle ears and roof of the nose. There is a consequent separation of the skull from the spine.

Reference:Textbook of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology: Principles & Practice 5th edition Page Nos. 274.

questions.text: A patient with submandibular gland cancer was posted for resection surgery. It was found that the level V lymph nodes were also involved and thus had to be removed. Which of the following groups of nodes may have been removed?
questions.solution:
There are 7 levels of lymph nodes in the neck-

Ia- Submental

Ib- Submandibular

II- Upper jugular nodes (behind upper part of SCM)

III- Mid Jugular nodes (behind middle part of SCM)

IV- Lower jugular nodes (below lower part of SCM)

V- Posterior triangle

VI- Delphian nodes, present between the hyoid bone and clavicle

VII- Mediastinal lymph nodes

The level of lymph nodes can be used to assess the spread of cancers and formulate treatment plans.



Reference: BD Chaurasia's human anatomy, regional and applied, 8th edition, volume-3 page 153.

choices.text: Safe in breastfeeding woman after 6 weeks of delivery
Delay in return of fertility after stopping the method

questions.text: All of the following statements are true regarding the image except-
questions.solution:
Depot-medroxyprogesterone acetate -

  • It is required every 3 months.
  • Dose is 150 mg.
  • It inhibits ovulation.
  • Safe in breastfeeding women after 6 weeks postpartum. It affects milk production slightly so it is better to give it after 6 weeks of delivery.
  • Fertility returns after 12 to 18 months of stoppage of the drug.
  • This method is the contraception of choice in- patients with epilepsy and sickle cell anemia. It reduces seizure frequency in epilepsy patients. It reduces the episodes of sickling in sickle cell anemia.

Reference: Dutta's Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition, Chapter- contraception, Page no 491

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl was brought to the emergency department by her grandparents. She had been found collapsed in the house whilst out of their sight for only a few minutes. She had been perfectly well before wandering into the kitchen on her own. There was no suggestion of trauma or a fall. The grandparents were worried that she may have eaten peanuts as these were found scattered on the floor. She was known to have asthma and eczema and the child's parents were concerned that she may have food allergies. Examination found her to be pale and floppy, responding poorly to stimuli. Her pulse was 160/minute, capillary refill was 5 seconds, and systolic blood pressure was 78mmHg. Oxygen saturation was 90% in the air. What is the next most important step in her management?
questions.solution:
• The history is highly suggestive of an acute anaphylactic reaction and is likely to deteriorate. Administration of adrenaline is the crucial first action whilst other actions are initiated.
  • 9% saline bolus 20 ml/kg-needed but obtaining IV access will create a delay.
  • Administer adrenaline 300 mcg IM-dose for those over 6 years
  • Administer hydrocortisone 100 mg IV-given after IM adrenaline and with IV access.

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20th ed., pg. 1134.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man has recently started taking estrogens from the physicians as it would help him become a 'female' by bringing about changes in his breast, voice and giving his body a feminine appearance. Over the past year, he has also changed his name in his documents and did procedures like body hair removal and facelift surgery. Since a child, he believes that his true identity is that of a 'female'. Pick the correct diagnosis.
questions.solution:
Gender dysphoria or gender incongruence refers to those persons with a marked incongruence between their experienced or expressed gender and the one they were assigned at birth. It was known as gender identity disorder in the previous edition of DSM.

This often leads to a desire to undergo hormonal treatment, surgery, or other healthcare services to make the individual's body align with the experienced gender.

The diagnosis cannot be assigned prior to the onset of puberty.

Transvestism refers to sexual arousal from cross-dressing. Fetischism refers to sexual arousal from the use of inert objects (like female undergarments). Both of these are included under paraphilic disorders.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, Eleventh edition, Chapter 18 Gender Dysphoria, page no. 600.

choices.text: Immediate precipitating factors are usually present

questions.text: All of the following features help in differentiating seizure from syncope except
questions.solution:
Usually syncope will have immediate precipitating factor like emotional stress, Valsalva, orthostatic hypotension, cardiac etiologies.

  • Tongue bite is rarely seen in syncope.
  • Unconsciousness lasts only for seconds in syncope.
  • Tonic-clonic movements in syncope are never > 15 seconds.


Reference - Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 21st edition, page 3316.

questions.text: Which is the innermost layer of corneal epithelium?
questions.solution:
Corneal epithelium is composed of non-keratinized, non-secretory, stratified squamous epithelium, which is 4-6 cell layers thick (40-50 µm).

  • The most superficial cells of the corneal epithelium are flat, polygonal cells. This layer is about 2-3 cellsdeep.
  • Extensive apical microvilli and microplicae characterize the cell membranes of the superficial cells, which in turn are covered by a fine, closely apposed, charged glycocalyceal layer.
  • Laterally, adjacent superficial cells are joined by barrier-tight-junctional complexes, which restrict the entry of tears into the intercellular spaces. Thus, a healthy epithelial surface repels dyes such as fluorescein and rose bengal.
  • Beneath the superficial cell layer are the suprabasal or wing cells, so named for their cross-sectional alar shapes. This layer is about 2-3 cells deep and consists of cells that are less flat than the overlying superficial cells but possess similar tight, lateral, and intercellular junctions.
  • Beneath the wing cells are the basal cells, which comprise the deepest cellular layer of the corneal epithelium. The basal cell layer is composed of a single-cell layer of columnar epithelium approximately 20 µm tall.

Corneal epithelial cells undergo orderly involution, apoptosis, and desquamation. Completeturnover of corneal epithelial cells occurs in about 7-10 days, with the deeper cells eventually replacing the desquamating superficial cells in an apically directed fashion.



Reference: Yanoff 4/e, p. 163-164

questions.solution: Reference - Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21e, page 2149

questions.text: Which of the following is not a DMARD used for the treatment of Rheumatoid arthritis?

questions.text: A person had protein deficiency. Which of the following cells are responsible for maintaining the catabolic state that the person presented with?
questions.solution:
• Plasma Proteins as a Source of Amino Acids for the Tissues.
  • When the tissues become depleted of proteins, the plasma proteins can act as a source of rapid replacement.
  • Indeed, whole plasma proteins can be imbibed in Toto by tissue macrophages through the process of pinocytosis; once in these cells, they are split into amino acids that are transported back into the blood and used throughout the body to build cellular proteins wherever needed.
  • In this way, the plasma proteins function as a labile protein storage medium and represent a readily available source of amino acids whenever a particular tissue requires them.

Reference: Guyton and hall 2nd southeast Asia edition pg.112.

questions.text: In subtrochanteric fractures, the proximal fragment is commonly
questions.solution:
In subtrochanteric fractures, the proximal fragment is commonly Flexed, abducted, externally rotated.

The typical displacements in a subtrochanteric fracture are depicted below.

questions.text: A 5-year-old male presented with dark color urine 1 to 2 days after an upper respiratory tract infection. Urine examination: RBC +++, albumin +; blood urea: 25 mg/dl; serum creatinine: 0.6 mg/dl; with normal serum complement. Poor prognostic indicators at follow-up include all of the following except
questions.solution:
This is a case of postinfectious glomerulonephritis.

  • Recurrent macroscopic hematuria is a good prognostic indicator.
  • All other options are poor prognosis.

Reference: Nelson pediatric symptom-based diagnosis, pg. 328.

questions.text: Prognostic index of Nazer is used for:
questions.solution:
Prognostic index of Nazer is used in Wilson's Disease.

Absent line of redness around wound

questions.solution:
Carboxyhemoglobin in the blood is seen in an antemortem burn.

choices.text: Microalbuminuria is not a predictor of macrovascular disease
Risk factors include high blood pressure, poor glycemic control, and smoking
There is established microalbuminuria if 2 out of 3 tests are positive
Microalbuminuria is present if albumin:creatinine ratio is 2.5-30 mg/mmol creatinine in men

questions.text: A 54-year-old man presents with long-standing diabetes mellitus and hypertension. You intend to screen for diabetic nephropathy by measuring microalbuminuria. Which of the following statements is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Screening for microalbuminuria -

  • Screening identifies incipient nephropathy in type 1 and type 2 diabetes.
  • Microalbuminuria is an independent predictor of macrovascular disease in diabetes.
  • Risk factors include high blood pressure, poor glycaemic control, and smoking.
  • Early morning urine is measured for albumin: creatinine ratio (ACR).
  • Microalbuminuria is present if:
  • ACR is 2.5-30 mg/mmol creatinine in men
  • ACR is 3.5-30 mg/mmol creatinine in women
  • An elevated ACR should be followed by a repeat test:
  • There is established microalbuminuria if 2 out of 3 tests are positive.
  • An ACR > 30 mg/mmol creatinine is consistent with overt nephropathy.

Reference: Davidson's principles and practice of medicine. 24th ed. Page 758. Box 20.39.

choices.text: It's a soft-blowing systolic murmur heard on the sides of the pregnant uterus
It is synchronous with the maternal pulse
It is due to increased blood flow through the umbilical arteries
It can be heard over a big fibroid as well

questions.text: All of the following are related to uterine souffle except-
questions.solution:
Funic or fetal souffle is due to the rush of blood through the umbilical arteries. It is a soft, blowing murmur synchronous with the fetal heart sounds

Uterine souffle is a soft blowing and systolic murmur heard low down at the sides of the uterus, best on the left side. The sound is synchronous with the maternal pulse and is due to an increase in blood flow through the dilated uterine vessels. It can be heard in the big uterine fibroid.

Reference: William's Obstetrics 26th edition, Page no 182.

questions.text: Developmental hypothalamic dysfunction with anosmia is:
questions.solution:
Kallmann syndrome results from defective hypothalamic gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) synthesis and is associated with anosmia or hyposmia due to olfactory bulb agenesis or hypoplasia.

Classically, the syndrome may also be associated with color blindness, optic atrophy, nerve deafness, cleft palate, renal abnormalities, cryptorchidism, and neurologic abnormalities such as mirror movements.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 20e, Page 2664.

questions.text:
A 64-year-old man, who has worked for a long period of his life as a boiler lagger, presents to the clinic for dyspnea and a dry cough of 1-year duration. He also reports that his fingers have begun to change shape. There are inspiratory basal crackles. CXR shows pleural calcifications.
What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient has a history of exposure to asbestos from working in the boiler industry.

Industries associated with occupational exposure to asbestos include mining, milling, and manufacturing, and many workers in the shipbuilding and construction trades, including pipe fitters and boilermakers.

Features seen in asbestosis include -

  • Restrictive pattern on pulmonary function testing.
  • Lower lobe involvement
  • Pleural involvement is seen first.
  • Calcified pleural plaques are seen.
  • Lung biopsy specimen shows several dumbbell-shaped ferruginous bodies, which are collections of iron and protein-coating asbestos fibers.

Asbestosis means that the changes seen here include signs of fibrosis on examination and hypoxia.

Progressive lung fibrosis occurs, eventually leading to respiratory failure, and the fibrotic changes are non-steroid responsive.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition Ch:283 Pg:1977-1978.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child is seen in the emergency department after having a seizure at home. This is the first time that this has happened. The mother says that the child was sitting on the couch watching television when she suddenly became limp, started drooling, and had generalized tonic-clonic movements of her arms and legs. The mother relates that the child had a high fever and that the tonic-clonic activity stopped after a few minutes. The mother says that the child is otherwise healthy, does not take any medicines, and has never been hospitalized. The child's immunizations are up-to-date, and she has no known drug allergies. On examination, the vital signs are temperature of 104°F, BP 98/54mmHg, HR 112, and RR 26. The child is sitting on the examination table playing. She has a mild amount of clear nasal congestion but her examination is otherwise normal. When asked, the child replies that she feels fine. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Febrile seizures are the most common cause of seizures in childhood.
  • These are classically seen early in an illness and when there is a rapid rise in the child's temperature.
  • These seizures usually last less than 2-3 minutes (typical febrile seizures last no longer than 15 minutes) and have a very mild, short, postictal phase.
  • Children who have seizures that are the result of bacterial meningitis will not subsequently be normal.
  • For typical febrile seizures, in an otherwise healthy and well-appearing child, no evaluation (outside of treating any underlying cause of the fever) is warranted.
  • Blood and urine cultures would not be necessary for the evaluation of the seizures, but they may be warranted in the evaluation of the fever.
  • An EEG and head CT will nearly universally be normal and are unwarranted.
  • A single typical febrile seizure routinely does not require any anticonvulsant therapy.
  • If the child has had multiple febrile seizures, or the seizures are not typical, anticonvulsant therapy may be entertained.
  • Prophylactic anticonvulsant therapy is usually initiated after the third febrile seizure.

Occasionally, children may have convulsions associated with fevers that do not fall into the typical features.

Some criteria which would make a febrile seizure atypical would be -

  • Prolonged duration (greater than 15 minutes)
  • Prolonged post-ictal state.

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20th ed., pg. 2830.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true for Magistrate inquest?
1. Sec. 176 CrPC deals with magistrate inquest.
2. Not allowed in cases of death while in police custody.
3. Arrest warrant cannot be issued for the accused
4. Allowed for the suicide of a woman within 7 years of marriage
5. Witness statements are not admissible in court
questions.solution:
The statements true for magistrate inquest are 1 and 4.

Sec. 176 CrPC deals with Magistrate inquest or inquiry into the cause of death wherein the circumstances of death are not due to natural causes. Magistrate inquest may be conducted by District Magistrate, Judicial Magistrate, Sub-Divisional Magistrate, or any Executive Magistrate empowered by the State Government (a Sub-Collector or a Tehsildar).

While this type of inquest is practiced all over the country, it is not routinely held.

Indications for a Magistrate inquest include the following:

  • Cases of exhumation.
  • Deaths due to dowry (suicide or death of a woman within 7 years of marriage).
  • Deaths due to police firing.
  • Disappearance/death of a person while in police custody or during police interrogation.
  • Death of a convict while in jail.
  • The alleged rape of a woman while in police custody.

Other statements:

The statements in the question stem compare the salient features of the Magistrate inquest and Police inquest (Sec. 174 CrPC). The latter is conducted by a police officer who is not qualified in law or medicine.

Statement 2- Death while in police custody is a valid reason for a Magistrate inquest.

Statement 3 - An arrest warrant can be issued against the accused in a Magistrate inquest.

Although a warrant cannot be issued in a police inquest, the accused may be arrested if there is a cognizable offense.

Statement 5 - Witness statements made during the course of a Magistrate inquest are valuable and admissible in court.

Witness statements made during the course of a Police inquest have no value and are not admissible in court.

Reference: Review Of Forensic Medicine And toxicology Including Clinical And Pathological Aspects Page Nos. 43.

questions.text: X-Rays are?
questions.solution:
X-rays belong to a group of radiations called electromagnetic radiation. Electromagnetic radiation is the transport of energy through space as a combination of electric and magnetic fields (hence the name electromagnetic).

Electromagnetic radiation includes radio waves, radiant heat, visible light, and gamma radiation.

Reference: Christensen's Physics of diagnostic radiology page pg 1.

questions.text: What is the leading cause of death in patients with chronic kidney disease?
questions.solution:
The leading cause of morbidity and mortality in patients with CKD regardless of the stage is cardiovascular disease. The presence of CKD is a major risk factor for ischemic heart disease,

In addition to traditional cardiovascular risk factors, patients with CKD have additional risk factors including anemia, hyperphosphatemia, hyperparathyroidism, sleep apnea, and systemic inflammation. Left ventricular hypertrophy and dilated cardiomyopathy are also frequently present in CKD and strongly associated with cardiovascular morbidity and mortality.

Reference - Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition, Chapter 305.

questions.text: Tomcat urine is characteristic of deficiency of which of the following condition?
questions.solution:
Tomcat urine is characteristic of multiple carboxylase deficiency.


Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20th ed., pg. 635.

questions.solution: Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 20e: Page 2735. Table 379-9.

questions.text: A patient is comfortable at rest, but less than ordinary activity causes fatigue. Which NYHA class does he fit into?
questions.solution: Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21e, Page 1798.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of severe pain in both her wrist joints and her fingers for the past 24 hours, every single morning. Examination shows swelling and tenderness of the wrists and MCP joints bilaterally. There are subcutaneous, non-tender, firm, mobile nodules on the extensor surface of the forearm. Which of the following is the most appropriate acute treatment for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Symptomatic treatment of acute flares of rheumatoid arthritis (i.e., episodes of increased disease activity) consists of temporary administration of anti-inflammatory drugs such as glucocorticoids (e.g., prednisolone) and/or NSAIDs.

A short course of glucocorticoids is more effective than NSAID therapy at reducing symptoms of inflammatory synovitis such as joint tenderness and pain. Glucocorticoids can either be administered systemically or via intraarticular injections (e.g., with triamcinolone acetonide). Glucocorticoids should be used at the lowest effective dose and only for short periods of time (< 3 months) to reduce the risk of their many adverse effects (e.g., hypertension, osteoporosis, infections).

In patients with peptic ulcer disease, the risk of gastrointestinal complications from glucocorticoids alone is low, which is why glucocorticoids are not contraindicated. However, in this patient group, glucocorticoids should not be combined with NSAIDs, because this significantly increases the rate of gastrointestinal complications.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 227.

Increase in blood oxygen carrying capacity

questions.text: A 53-year-old man with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and obesity takes a beta-blocker, angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor, and a statin. His LDL cholesterol remains elevated. You decide to prescribe another medication to improve his lipid profile. One month later, you receive a telephone call from your patient; he complains of turning bright red and feeling 'scorching hot' every time he takes his medications. In order to alleviate the patient's symptoms, which of the following medications would you recommend?
questions.solution:
This patient is exhibiting flushing and warmth due to the administration of a non-statin lipid-lowering medication. This is a classic side effect of niacin (nicotinic acid). Aspirin is commonly given as a pretreatment to alleviate niacin-induced flushing.

This flushing is thought to be mediated by prostaglandin release. When aspirin is administered 30-60 minutes prior to niacin administration, its anti-prostaglandin effects can prevent or minimize niacin-induced flushing. Other techniques commonly used to decrease niacin side effects include eating food while taking the medication and administration of a controlled-release form of niacin (Niaspan).

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 682.

choices.text: Assess the blood flow to any organ

questions.text: Ultrasound doppler is used in?
questions.solution:
• When high-frequency sound impinges on a stationary interface, the reflected ultrasound has essentially the same frequency or wavelength as the transmitted sound.
  • If the reflecting interface is moving with respect to the sound beam emitted from the transducer, however, there is a change in the frequency of the sound scattered by the moving object.
  • This change in frequency is directly proportional to the velocity of the reflecting interface relative to the transducer and is a result of the Doppler effect.
  • This helps in assessing the flow in the vessels.

Reference: Christensen's Physics of diagnostic radiology page 351.

questions.text: A 15-month-old boy comes to the ER with vomiting and constipation for 3 days. He also has growth retardation. No significant birth history, birth weight was 3kg. But he was never able to bear weight and walk. His speech, vision, and hearing were thought to be normal. His parents are first cousins, having 3 live children all normal but 2 children have died under the age of 2 years all with a similar illness. On examination, weight and height are below the 3rd centile, head circumference is at the 50th centile. The child is extremely wasted and dehydrated and had swelling of wrists and bowing of lower limbs. There is hypotonia, but no focal neurological deficit. The rest of the examination is normal. Investigations show hyponatremia, hypokalemia, acidosis, and elevated urea. Glucose, calcium, and phosphate are normal but ALP is 1560 U/l (very high). Urine pH is 6, protein +, glucose trace. The most likely explanation for this condition is?
questions.solution:
The child is presenting with vomiting, growth retardation, clinical features of rickets, acidosis, and low sodium and potassium. Fanconi syndrome consists of renal tubular acidosis affecting the proximal tubule together with minor aciduria, glycosuria, phosphaturia, and hypokalemia. Cystinosis is the most likely cause given the family history of autosomal recessive inheritance.

Barter syndrome has polydipsia, hyponatremia, and alkalosis.

MCAD deficiency has hypoglycemia as the main feature and would not explain rickets

Mucopolysaccharidosis has developmental delay as the main feature and does not explain rickets.

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20th ed., pg. 3135.

choices.text: Abnormally low level of glutathione activity
Inhibition of ferrochelatase and ALA dehydratase

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman, Alia presents to the clinic for fatigue and lightheadedness for the past week. He was recently diagnosed with active tuberculosis and started treatment 2 weeks ago. A peripheral blood smear is shown in the figure below. What is the most likely explanation for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient has sideroblastic anemia (e.g., fatigue, palpitations, lightheadedness with a history of isoniazid use, and basophilic stippling on peripheral blood smear). This is due to his isoniazid use (part of the standard treatment for active tuberculosis), which leads to a drug-induced deficiency in vitamin B6.

Sideroblastic anemia is a form of anemia in which the body is unable to incorporate iron into hemoglobin. Therefore, the bone marrow produces ringed sideroblasts (nucleated erythroblasts) rather than healthy red blood cells. This disorder can be caused by a genetic disorder, hematological malignancies, or reversible causes (e.g., alcohol, lead, or vitamin B6 deficiency.)

Patients often present with nonspecific symptoms associated with anemia, which include pallor, dizziness, and fatigue. Isoniazid, which is one of the standard medications for active tuberculosis, interferes with pyridoxine metabolism and leads to vitamin B6 deficiency. Vitamin B6 is needed for heme synthesis as it acts as the cofactor for the first step of heme synthesis. Therefore, patients who are started on isoniazid are to be given pyridoxine/vitamin B6 supplements to prevent sideroblastic anemia.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 968.

questions.text: What is the most likely etiology for the image below?
questions.solution:
Hypertensive intracranial hemorrhage (hICH) is the acute manifestation of non-traumatic ICH secondary to systemic HTN.

Sites of hICH -

  • The putamen/external capsule is the most common
  • The thalamus is the next most common site.
  • The pons and cerebellum are the third most common location and cause 10% of all hICHs.

Multiple microbleeds are common in patients with chronic HTN. HTN-related microbleeds tend to cluster in the basal ganglia and cerebellum with fewer lesions in the cortex and subcortical white matter.

Appearance -

  • The most common gross finding in hICH is a large ganglionic hematoma that often extends medially into the ventricles.
  • NECT scans typically show a round or ovoid hyperdense mass centered in the lateral putamen/external capsule or thalamus.
  • In the presence of active bleeding or coagulopathy, the hemorrhage may appear inhomogeneously hyperdense with lower-density areas and even fluid-fluid levels.
  • Intraventricular extension is common.
  • Acute hICH does not enhance on CECT.

Reference: Osborn Brain edition 2 page 116.

choices.text: Abnormal neuronal activity in the brain
Medication side effect due to drug-to-drug interaction
Neurologically induced drop in blood pressure

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after passing out at work. A coworker who accompanied the patient claims that she bit her tongue during the episode but denies any shaking or jerking. The episode lasted about 15 minutes. Her past medical history includes GERD, for which she takes cimetidine. She is currently taking azithromycin for a chlamydial infection diagnosed 3 days ago. Physical examination is unremarkable except for mild tachycardia and suprapubic tenderness. An electrocardiogram (ECG) obtained during triage is shown in the image. What is the most likely explanation for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient had a syncopal episode secondary to QT prolongation caused by azithromycin. QT prolongation is a rare side effect of the drug and in this case, may have been exacerbated due to the potent cytochrome P-450 inhibitory effects of cimetidine. Therefore, this patient's symptoms are due to a medication side effect secondary to drug-to-drug interaction.

Cimetidine reversibly blocks histamine H2 receptors to decrease acid secretion from parietal cells, thus offering symptomatic relief for patients with peptic ulcer disease, gastritis, and esophageal reflux. It is a powerful inhibitor of the cytochrome P-450 system. Other notable inhibitor drugs include isoniazid, ketoconazole, omeprazole, ciprofloxacin, metronidazole, and fluconazole.

Medications such as azithromycin, which is metabolized via the cytochrome P-450 system, will cause greater side effects due to the drug-to-drug interaction. QT prolongation is a serious but rare side effect of macrolides and may present with lightheadedness, palpitations, syncope, and sudden cardiac death.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 695.

choices.text: Behavioral and psychological symptoms of dementia

questions.text: A 65-year-old man suffers from memory problems for the last six months. The main concern of the family members is that he experiences visual hallucinations all the time. He sees all dead relatives, especially his wife, and tries to establish conversations with her as if she is real. He also sees animals like cats and foxes at home and the faces of children. He fell down from the bed three or four times in the last six months. He suffered lacerations on his head due to the falls. These Hallucinations were gradual in onset, started 6 months ago; slowly becoming worse. The physician started him on Haloperidol but he developed stiffness in his limbs. He was diagnosed with Parkinson's roughly 9 months ago and he has been on medications since then. Pick his correct diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Lewy body disease is dementia clinically similar to Alzheimer's disease and often characterized by -

  • Recurrent visual hallucinations
  • Dementia with fluctuating cognition/ alertness
  • REM sleep behavoiur disorder.
  • They also have parkinsonian features and are sensitive to the side effects of antipsychotic

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, Eleventh edition, Chapter 21.3 Dementia (Major Neurocognitive disorder), page no. 709.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl, Reema approaches her dermatologist with the following lesions on her face. She has prescribed the application of 2 gels containing benzoyl peroxide and retinoic acid. She is asked to come for a follow-up after 8 weeks. However, when she returns, she complains that though she has been mixing these gels well and using them diligently, there has been no effect on her condition. What could be the reason for the same?
questions.solution:
Used as a 0.025-0.05% gel or cream, retinoic acid can be alternated with benzoyl peroxide (one in the morning the other at night), but both should not be applied together because benzoyl peroxide accelerates the degradation of tretinoin.

An analogue that does not interfere with benzoyl peroxide is Adapalene.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 953.

choices.text: They are formed for weight transmission
They are involved in joint formation

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about the structures marked in green and blue in the image given below?
questions.solution:
The greater trochanter (green) and lesser trochanter (blue) are examples of TRACTION EPIPHYSES.

  • They are formed due to pulling of muscles.
  • They do not take part in joint formation.

Other types of epiphysis are-

  • Pressure epiphysis- involved in joint formation, and transmits weight (eg- head of the femur)
  • Traction epiphysis
  • Atavistic epiphysis- fuse to surrounding bones mainly for nutrition- eg- coracoids process of scapula
  • Aberrant epiphysis- not usually present

Reference: BD Chaurasia's handbook of general anatomy, 4th edition, pg no 29.

Immunophenotype of the leukocytes showed Early Pre-B cell type of ALL. While counseling the parents about the prognosis, which of the following factor must be explained as having an unfavorable prognosis?
questions.solution: Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 2439.
