questions.text:
A: Acute infarct shows diffusion restriction
R: Brownian motion is free in acute infarct
questions.solution:
Cellular swelling begins to develop within minutes following an ischemic insult.

Apparent diffusion coefficient (ADC) values decrease, producing high signal intensity on diffusion-weighted imaging. This decrease is due to reduced water infusibility caused by decreased levels of astrocytic aquaporin-4 thus reducing the movement of water molecules in the brain.

Aquaporins are transmembrane proteins-water channels-that facilitate bidirectional selective water transport in and out of the cell.

The normal motion of water molecules within living tissues is random (Brownian motion). In acute ischemic stroke, a shortage of metabolites occurs, causing a Na+/K+ channel failure in every ischemic cell.

This membrane channel failure causes an alteration of the homeostasis of intracellular and extracellular water, which is normally maintained steady state. In consequence, excessive intracellular water accumulation leads to a narrowing of the extracellular matrix and thus to a reduction of Brownian molecular motion in the extracellular space.

Reference: Osborn Brain edition 2 pg 215

Acute stroke magnetic resonance imaging: current status and future perspective (nih.gov)

questions.text: Meenu, a 16-year-old suffered from a fall from a bike during a road traffic accident. Her head hit the gravel and she was immediately rushed to the ER. She was unconscious and her GCS was 7/15. She gained consciousness 2 hours later but complained of headache, neck stiffness, nausea, and was unable to walk. Accordingly, she was sent for head CT imaging and a lumbar puncture was also done. CT revealed edema in the brain parenchyma. Thus, suspecting cerebral edema, an I.V. osmotic diuretic was administered to her. Where on the nephron does this drug act?
questions.solution:
• The drug of choice to relieve cerebral edema, especially after trauma and stroke is IV Mannitol.
  • It is an osmotic diuretic.
  • Mannitol constitutes a new solute in the plasma, which increases the tonicity of the plasma.
  • Since mannitol cannot cross the intact blood-brain barrier, the increased tonicity from the mannitol draws water out of the brain parenchyma and into the intravascular space. The water then travels with the mannitol to the kidneys, where it gets excreted in the urine.
  • It is also a drug of choice in acute congestive glaucoma.
  • It acts on the loop of Henle

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 638.

questions.text: Mr. Majnu is a 67-year-old man with hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and coronary artery disease, and had triple bypass surgery 17 years ago. His current home medications include amlodipine, atorvastatin, and aspirin. He presents to the clinic with shortness of breath, which occurs when performing simple tasks such as sweeping the floor. Physical examination reveals elevated jugular venous pressure and 1+ pitting lower extremity edema. An echocardiogram demonstrates systolic dysfunction and an ejection fraction (EF) of 30%. Laboratory results show a pro-B-type natriuretic peptide level of 1302 pg/mL, a troponin level of <0.34, and an unremarkable basic metabolic panel (BMP). Measurement of vital signs shows blood pressure (BP) of 156/92 mm Hg, a heart rate of 80 beats/min, Spo2 of 94%, and a temperature of 36.5 °C. A diagnosis of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF) is made. Which of the following drugs acting on the cardiovascular system is contraindicated in these cases?
questions.solution:
Heart failure due to reduced ejection fraction or LVF should not be treated with calcium channel blockers because Non-DHP's like Verapamil and diltiazem directly depress cardiac contractility in an already failing heart whereas DHP's like Nifedipine cause reflex tachycardia. Thus, they are contraindicated.

Beta-blockers improve mortality in CHF patients by preventing cardiac remodeling by inhibition of the RAAS axis.

Digoxin is used to treat symptomatic CHF.

Ivabradine is an antianginal that blocks funny sodium current channels. It is recommended in CHF with HR >70bpm and EF <35% and symptomatic despite treatment with beta-blockers, ACE inhibitors, and spironolactone.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 568

questions.text: A 24-year-old primi para comes to the antenatal OPD for a routine checkup. She is diagnosed with hyperthyroidism. Which of the following anti-thyroid drugs is to be avoided in her?
questions.solution:
I131 is the most commonly used radioactive iodine with a half-life of 8 days (a stable isotope of iodine is I127). When administered (as sodium salts, orally), these are actively taken up by the thyroid gland and stored in the colloid. Here, it emits x-rays and β-particles. Latter can penetrate only 0.5-2mm of tissue and destroy the gland from within. The concentration of radioactive iodine in the thyroid gland is responsible for its selective thyroid-destroying effect.

I131 can be used for the treatment of hyperthyroidism but the response is slow (maximum response may take 3 months).

Thyroid peroxidase inhibitors are administered to make the patient euthyroid. After a gap of 5 days (after stopping anti-thyroid drugs), radioactive iodine is given and thyroid peroxidase inhibitor treatment is resumed till the effect of I131 starts.

Radioactive iodine therapy is primarily indicated for patients older than 35 years, those with heart disease, and in the presence of other contraindications of surgery.

These drugs are not suitable for young children and during pregnancy.

Propylthiouracil is the drug of choice for hyperthyroidism in the first trimester of pregnancy and lactation.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 277-278.

choices.text: All of the above can occur

questions.text: What is the most common gestational trophoblastic neoplasia after the hydatiform mole?
questions.solution:
Invasive mole is the most common trophoblastic neoplasm that follows a hydatiform mole, and almost all invasive moles arise from partial or complete moles.

Reference: William's obstetrics 26th edition, Page no 242.

questions.text: Which of the following contributes to the compressive strength of the bone?
questions.solution:
The compressive strength of bone denotes the capacity of the bone to withstand compressive force. It is provided by:

  • Calcium Hydroxyapatite- forms the major inorganic constituent of the bone.
  • Hyaluronic acid and chondroitin sulfate molecules are the organic constituents having an important role in maintaining the integrity of the extracellular matrix of bone and cartilage.

Note that the 'compressive strength' should not be confused with the 'tensile strength' of bone which denotes the capacity of the bone to withstand tensile (elongation) force. It is provided by Type 1 Collagen.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry 31/ Pg 1473.

choices.text: A 32-year-old with cerebral edema due to TB meningitis
A COVID-positive patient in septicaemic shock

questions.text: Steroids are used with caution in many emergencies. Which of the following cases is a contraindication for the usage of steroids?
questions.solution:
Steroids are contraindicated in intestinal (Ileocaecal) TB due to the risk of perforation.

Contraindications to corticosteroid usage include -

  • Peptic ulcer
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Hypertension
  • Viral and fungal infections
  • Tuberculosis and other infections
  • Osteoporosis
  • Herpes simplex keratitis
  • Psychosis
  • Epilepsy
  • CHF
  • Renal failure

Option a - Steroids with selective glucocorticoid action (without Na+ and water retaining activity) like betamethasone and dexamethasone are used to decrease cerebral edema due to malignancies or TB.

Option b - Administered under effective chemotherapeutic cover, corticosteroids are indicated only in serious infective diseases to tide over the crisis or to prevent complications. They are indicated in conditions like severe forms of tuberculosis (miliary, meningeal, renal, etc.), severe lepra reaction, certain forms of bacterial meningitis, and Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia with hypoxia in AIDS patients.

Option c - These can be used as a desperate measure in septicemic shock, especially in patients who are adrenal deficient and who do not respond adequately to fluid replacement and vasopressors.

Other uses of steroids -

  • Deflazacort is recently approved for the oral treatment of Duchenne's muscular dystrophy.
  • Steroids can also be used for the treatment of sarcoidosis.
  • In thrombocytopenia, prednisolone is used to decrease bleeding tendency.
  • Autoimmune hemolytic anemia is treated with prednisolone.
  • Significant decrease in neurological defects have been seen in spinal cord injury patients treated with large doses of methylprednisolone (within 8 hours).

Reference - Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 318.

questions.text: Which of the following X-rays best corresponds to consolidation?
questions.solution:
Consolidation is seen as a soft tissue opacity in the lung fields obscuring the normal bronchovascular markings. Sometimes air bronchogram can also be seen through it as the trachea and bronchi are filled with air and seen as radiolucencies through the consolidation.

Reference: Thoracic Imaging Pulmonary and Cardiovascular Radiology edition 3, page 16.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents for a well-child visit. His mother notes that he breathes fast and his lips turn 'dusky' when he runs or plays hard. The symptoms resolve once he stops the activity. On examination, he has a II/VI left upper sternal border systolic murmur that radiates to the back; a faint click is heard. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this child's exercise intolerance?
questions.solution:
Although pulmonary stenosis and tricuspid atresia are cyanotic heart lesions, exercise-induced cyanosis and systolic murmur are characteristic of pulmonary stenosis.

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20th ed., pg. 2202

questions.text: What is this effect demonstrated by Ephedrine administration on blood pressure known as?
questions.solution:
Repeated dosing of a drug, especially indirectly acting sympathomimetics like ephedrine and tyramine produce a lesser response. This is known as tachyphylaxis.



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, pg no - 80-81.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presented with a 1-week history of severe right-sided headache associated with reduced vision in his right, amblyopic eye. Examination revealed raised intraocular pressure at 64 mm Hg. The anterior chamber (AC) was shallow and there was a dense cataract with no red reflex or fundal view. Which of the following agents is the drug of choice in this type of glaucoma?
questions.solution:
The case describes acute angle closure glaucoma, for which the drug of choice is pilocarpine.

Pilocarpine (directly acting cholinomimetic) and physostigmine (indirectly acting cholinomimetic) increase aqueous outflow by causing miosis.

Dorsolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor that reduces aqueous outflow.

Dipevefrine is a prodrug of adrenaline, which increases both trabecular and uveoscleral outflow and reduces secretion.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition - 153.

questions.text: Gestational Diabetes is associated with which of the following malformation in the fetus?
questions.solution:
Gestational diabetes usually develops in the second trimester of pregnancy when organogenesis has already been completed.

For malformations to develop hyperglycemia should be present in 1st trimester of pregnancy during organogenesis.

Fetal malformations are seen in women with pre-gestational diabetes.

All of the above-mentioned complications can be seen in infants of diabetic mothers with poorly controlled diabetes in the first trimester.

Women can be separated into those diagnosed with diabetes before pregnancy- Pre-gestational or overt diabetes and those diagnosed during pregnancy- gestational diabetes.

Reference: Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition, Page no 327.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy falls from a highchair during a rowdy game of 'Go Fish' and falls onto an outstretched right hand. He presents to the emergency department with complaints that he can't move his arm. X-rays reveal a Gartland type III extension-type supracondylar fracture. His fingers are warm and well-perfused, but no radial pulse is palpable. On careful examination, with which of the following motions is he most likely to have difficulty?
questions.solution:
The 'okay' sign, made by flexing the thumb and index finger to make a ring, test thumb IP flexion and index finger DIP flexion, two tasks specific to the anterior interosseous nerve (AIN), which is a branch of the median nerve.

The AIN is most commonly injured in extension-type supracondylar fractures.

Thumbs up and wrist extension are functions of the radial nerve- the second most commonly injured nerve with extension-type injuries.

Thumb and small finger opposition rely mostly on the thenar eminence (pollicis opponens), which is innervated by the recurrent median nerve.

NEUROLOGICAL COMPLICATIONS (7-10%) OF SUPRA CONDYLAR HUMERUS FRACTURE

This may be caused by a traction injury at the time of the fracture or very rarely at the time of reduction. The neurovascular structures may be tented or entrapped in the fracture site. Neurologic injury is also a component of Volkmann ischemic contracture. Most injuries seen from supracondylar humerus fractures are neurapraxia, requiring no treatment. Nerves involved include -

  • Median nerve/anterior interosseous nerve (most common)
  • Radial nerve
  • Ulnar nerve: This is most common in flexion-type supracondylar fractures.
  • Early injury - May result from tenting over the medial spike of the proximal fragment
  • Late injury - May represent progressive valgus deformity of the elbow.
  • It can be iatrogenic in extension-type supracondylar fractures, especially following medial entry fixation.

Reference: Egol, K. A., Koval, K. J., & Zuckerman, J. D. (Eds.). (2020). Glenohumeral Dislocation. In Handbook of Fractures (6th ed., pp.601). Lippincott Williams & Wilkins.

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient was admitted for pneumonia. On the second postoperative day, he developed a high-grade fever. Culture reports were positive for MRSA infection. The patient was administered IV Vancomycin for the same. He developed diffuse flushing 2 hours later as shown in the image. Which of the following is the mechanism behind this finding in the patient?
questions.solution:
• The given side effect is RED MAN SYNDROME, which is the most common adverse effect of rapid IV infusion of large doses of Vancomycin.
  • Red man syndrome is an infusion-related reaction peculiar to vancomycin.
  • It typically consists of pruritus, an erythematous rash that involves the face, neck, and upper torso. Less frequently, hypotension and angioedema can occur.
  • A dose of 50 mg diphenhydramine hydrochloride intravenously or orally can abort most of the reactions.
  • Once the rash and itching dissipate, the infusion can be resumed at a slower rate and/or at a lesser dosage.
  • Hypotension will require intravenous fluids and, if severe, vasopressors may be needed.

Vancomycin is a bactericidal glycopeptide antibiotic that inhibits cell wall synthesis by inhibiting the transglycosylase enzyme (involved in chain elongation).

It has a narrow spectrum and is effective against gram-positive organisms including MRSA, penicillin-resistant pneumococci, and Clostridium difficile. It is a drug of choice for MRSA, and for serious infections in penicillin-allergic patients.

Other toxic effects of vancomycin are chills, ototoxicity, and nephrotoxicity. Its dose should be decreased in renal failure.

Teicoplanin does not cause red man syndrome or nephrotoxicity. Its mechanism of action and spectrum of activity is similar to vancomycin.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition - 806.

questions.text: Which of the following is the gold standard investigation for visualization of aneurysms?
questions.solution:
Digital subtraction angiography (DSA) is considered the 'gold standard' in vascular imaging. Diagnostic indications for DSA include -

  • Assessing for aneurysms in subarachnoid hemorrhage when CTA/MR are negative
  • Accurate assessment of arteriovenous malformations
  • Intracerebral hemorrhage of unknown etiology.

Reference: Imaging in neurology, 2016.

questions.text: A 34-year-old sexually active male presented with multiple grouped vesicles on his genitalia. There was no lymphadenopathy and the blisters were a recurrent problem for the last 7 months. Which of the following STD packets will you prescribe to this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features suggesting multiple, recurring vesicles in groups suggest herpes infection.


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 814.

questions.text: Which of the following scenarios would impart bright pink-colored postmortem staining?
questions.solution:
Refrigeration imparts a bright pink patchy color to the postmortem staining. This is because of oxyhemoglobin retention within the tissues due to decreased oxygen uptake by tissues. It is also commonly seen in hypothermia and victims of drowning as wet skin is permeable to atmospheric oxygen. Hemoglobin has a greater affinity for oxygen at lower temperatures.

The normal color of PM staining is reddish-purple. This color varies based on the oxygenation status of the body at the time of death.


Reference: Textbook of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology: Principles & Practice 5th edition, Page No. 83.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman, Ruksar had left home 3 days ago because she thought her family was poisoning her and has since been listed as a missing person. She has never been prescribed psychiatric medications before but is amenable to starting a medication now. She has a history of obesity and pre-diabetes. Which of the following would be the most appropriate as a first-line medication for her?
questions.solution:
Psychotic disorders are treated with typical (also known as the first generation) and/or atypical (second and third generation) antipsychotic medications. The main difference between these two classes is a lower risk of extrapyramidal side effects among the atypical antipsychotics. As such, first-line treatment is usually with an atypical antipsychotic (other than clozapine), with the specific agent chosen based on the minimization of particular adverse effects.

For this patient with obesity and pre-diabetes, for example, medications with the highest metabolic risk (olanzapine and clozapine) should be avoided, if possible.

Risperidone is a high-potency atypical antipsychotic (that is, it has a relatively high affinity for dopamine receptors and low affinity for other receptors,( e.g., histaminergic receptors, at low doses) that is often used as a first-line treatment for psychosis.

Clozapine is not used as the first-line because of its risk of agranulocytosis; however, it is indicated for patients who have failed treatment with other antipsychotics, since it is the most efficacious.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 462.

questions.text: Turner's syndrome is associated with which cardiac malformation?
questions.solution:
• Turner's syndrome is associated with the bicuspid aortic valve.
  • PDA usually follows rubella infection in early pregnancy
  • Overt diabetes can result in VSD.
  • Lithium ingestion by the mother during pregnancy is associated with Ebstein's anomaly
  • Down syndrome is associated with endocardial cushion defect.

Reference: William' obstetrics 26th edition, Page no 314.
